TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Was any decision made as to when and where the decision made by Cabinet on the amount of money to be offered to the States at the Premiers Conference would be announced, to which media outlets it would be circulated and what other media steps would be taken? I further ask the Minister to note that I am asking not for details of a substantive Cabinet decision but for information on how the decision was to be released. I ask the Minister to treat the question in the light of that qualification.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps, in the light of the fact that the question is broader than a question for the Treasurer, I will take it. Later I will be making a broader statement on the whole of these procedures. The fact is that the Minister in charge, in general terms, is competent to announce any decision of the Cabinet. It is necessary to indicate that every Premier who comes to the Premiers Conference does so with instructions and with limitations upon his capacity to discuss and negotiate. These are imposed on him by his own Government and his own Cabinet.

ANSWER.PARA: The representatives of the eight governments at the Premiers Conference each came with particular advice and instructions from his own Cabinet. It is a matter of common knowledge and not any surprise to anyone that negotiating parameters are the practice of all governments. There was never any need for that to be made known. Any thinking person in the community and any member of the Press would know that. Therefore, there is no need for a statement to be made to the general public. As I understand the specific case, a reply was made to a question and the answer obviously stated the obvious, and that was that our Government, along with other governments, and negotiating parameters with which it came to the table.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether the announcement at the Premiers Conference of the amount of tax reimbursement to be made available to the States was not in fact a statement of Government policy. As to any subsequent statement, was any decision made by the Cabinet to announce to the media that that which was released at the Premiers Conference was not a statement of Government policy?

—In the statement I will be pointing out that, as with other governments which came to the table at the Premiers Conference, the Federal Government came with negotiating parameters. The Federal Government has been pursuing policies, which have been applauded throughout Australia, of economic efficiency and economic restraint so as to keep down inflation, to allow enterprise to expand and to create more job opportunities. That policy has been applauded over recent weeks and months widely throughout Australia. The Federal Government has pursued those policies. In regard to tax sharing arrangements the Federal Government had a responsibility to seek a similar restraint by the States. It sought that restraint. It was told, by way of Cabinet parameters, that it must seek the most significant restraint it could achieve. It was given an absolute upper limit of real terms; that is, to retain the same value in purchasing power for the coming year. That upper limit, as such, would have been described as somewhere between 9 1/2 per cent and 10 per cent. It would have imposed no particular restraint upon the States to take more efficient measures. The agreement that was reached was perfectly within the hands of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to reach. It was part of a Cabinet decision that within those parameters they were empowered to reach an agreement. The agreement that was reached was 9 per cent. It was announced, and it was wholly within the Cabinet's decision so to reach that agreement.

—The Attorney-General will recollect that on 28 April I asked him about statements attributed to Mr Justice Barblett of the Family Court of Australia, which sought to make a case for bringing de facto relationships into family law. Is the Attorney-General aware that the judge took a most unusual step in arranging for the Press to be told beforehand that he would be delivering a judgment in the Family Court about these de facto relationships? Can the Attorney-General confirm that this is a highly unusual circumstance, as normally even important Family Court judgments are not reported? Has the Attorney heard any details about the case now concluded, particularly about the basis of ex parte orders made? Has the Attorney seen an article on page 26 of yesterday's Perth Daily News which alleges substantial irregularities in Mr Justice Barblett's handing of the case? Is the Attorney aware that Mr Justice Barblett arranged publicity for his statement without the knowledge or approval of the parties involved? Has the Attorney heard from the Child Welfare Department of Western Australia, which is considerably aggrieved, about aspects of the matter concerning the children? Finally, will the Attorney please get the full details of this matter and inform the Senate?

—The Family Court of Western Australia is a State court set up by its State Parliament and invested with jurisdiction under the Family Law Act of this Parliament and also under State legislation. I thought I explained some of those features of the Western Australian State Family Court in answer to the previous question which Senator Martyr asked me about that. I reiterate that it is a State court. Mr Justice Barblett and the other judges of that Court are appointed by the State Government. The procedures of that Court are under State legislation, even though a substantial part of its jurisdiction is under the Family Law Act. The matters that Senator Martyr has raised are, I believe, matters on which I will have to seek an answer from the Attorney-General of Western Australia. I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Attorney-General of Western Australia and endeavour to obtain an answer from him.

—My question is directed to Senator Carrick as Leader of the Government in the Senate and as Vice-President of the Executive Council. Will he tell the Senate what is the substance-I do not expect him to quote it verbatim-of the oath sworn by Ministers as members of the Executive Council?

—I do not think there is any confidentiality about the oath. I should like to get the text of it and see whether it can be made available to honourable senators. I will seek to do so. Prior to a Minister being sworn into a portfolio the first oath that is taken, as I recall it, is that of the Executive Council. That oath is in effect to advise the Queen or the Queen's viceroys to the best of one's ability and in full confidentiality. If that is not a complete recollection, I will see whether I can get the words.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank Senator Carrick. Will he tell us whether the oath obviates the need for all or any other sworn statements, as claimed by Mr Sinclair in a letter to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations? Is there any penalty for breaches of the Executive Council oath? If so, how does it compare with the penalty of four years' imprisonment for a conviction upon indictment for making a false statutory declaration?

—The main sanction that comes upon a member of parliament is the sanction of the chamber in which he has the privilege of serving. If that Minister, senator or member can be shown, within that chamber, to have misled or to have made a false statement-not on oath but any false statement-then that member, senator or Minister is subject to the discipline of the chamber. The real sanction, as I understand it, is not one which relates to the Executive Council oath. It is a wider sanction. The Executive Council advises the Governor-General or Her Majesty, as Queen of Australia. The real sanction is the presumption by the people of Australia-a correct and proper presumption in my judgment-that when a member, senator or Minister speaks, whether publicly outside this chamber or in this chamber and whether with or without parliamentary protection, he or she speaks truthfully. If that person does not speak truthfully, then the sanction of the chamber is heavily upon him or her. Therefore, I invite all honourable senators to presume that when a member of parliament makes a statement, whether written or oral, that person is making it with the same force as if it were made on oath.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Education aware that a false impression has been publicly circulating this week that the Government will cut off funding for 30 colleges of advanced education, whereas the decision from the Review of Commonwealth Functions which affects colleges of advanced education is seeking improvement, rationalisation and co-ordination to achieve multi-campus colleges under single managing councils along the lines already successful in South Australia and Tasmania and these newly arranged colleges will continue to be fully funded? Can the Minister clarify this decision for continuing Commonwealth support for these colleges on the basis of these new arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Essentially, what Senator Teague says is correct. There were, and probably still are, approximately 80 colleges in existence. Over time there has been a great proliferation of those colleges. The proliferation occurred when the Australian population was expanding rapidly, when it was a younging population and, therefore, when there was a great demand for more teachers to meet the population explosion. A considerable number of colleges existed. Many of them were teachers' colleges, which in 1971 or 1972 changed their names to colleges of advanced education and became single purpose teachers' colleges. Now the Australian population growth is virtually stagnant. There is a slow decline in the school population in the government school sector and an aging of the population. There is now very substantially less demand for teachers-there was an explosion in the number of teachers-and therefore the future need for a number of single purpose teacher-training colleges has been somewhat negated.

ANSWER.PARA: Both the Tertiary Education Commission and the Government have taken the view that there is a need for a regrouping and rearrangement of colleges so that they can be linked under a common administration to save money and to give better efficiency and better performance. It is not to be considered that this will abolish the colleges. It is a reform which was inevitable in terms of demographic movement. It will bring about improvements. If those groupings occur in the course of the year, the Tertiary Education Commission will consider funding each new grouping on a per capita basis as though it were a separate organisation. I understand that approximately $5m extra has been made available to allow for extra costs in these rearrangements. Certainly it would be wrong to believe that this move will destroy a number of colleges.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement, at his Press conference last night broadcast on the Nationwide special edition at 11 o'clock, that his revelation of the Cabinet's bargaining position with the Premiers was justified on freedom of information grounds. No doubt Senator Carrick will recall the exact words, which were:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . in this world in which freedom of information is so important why should the Press or anyone worry about the fact that the Treasurer in consultation with myself and I, last night, made it plain that we'd been given that kind of authority, . . .

That is to say, by the Cabinet. Does this statement mean that the Government is no longer implacably opposed to the revelation under the Freedom of Information Bill of Cabinet materials, even materials of the utmost sensitivity involving contemporaneous negotiating positions? If the Prime Minister did not mean this by his statement, then-given that he is not exactly famous for his wit, irony, sense of humour or general lightness of touch-what did he mean?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that Senator Evans would have started from an understanding of the day-to-day Cabinet procedures by which daily, and certainly weekly, quite a number of Cabinet decisions are made and in due course the Cabinet decisions are made available to the community through the responsible Minister. That is the normal situation. It does not need any recourse to the Freedom of Information Bill or any other matter at all; it is simply that, when a particular procedure has taken place and there is a particular timetable, unless Cabinet has decided for particular reasons that the decision shall not be made public at that time it is made public.

ANSWER.PARA: There is nothing at all secret about the fact that all governments-State and Federal-go to a negotiating table with parameters of negotiation defined by their respective Cabinets. That would be a presumption that every person would know and understand. There is no question of disclosing that. The fact is and the presumption is that everyone would understand it. I cannot believe that there can be any issue about that at all because, in respect of every Premiers Conference that has ever been held and every ministerial council meeting that is held in Australia, Ministers go to those conferences with what one could colloquially say would be riding instructions from their Cabinets.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can keep repeating that, but it has nothing to do with the issue, has it? Everybody knows that.

—If indeed Senator Button wants to make statements, let him make them, and not by way of interjection. I am asked whether there is any particular link between a change of heart on freedom of information and what the Prime Minister said last night. The answer is no. They are two totally different situations. It has been the practice always for Cabinet decisions in due course, assuming they are public decisions, to be made public by the responsible Minister. There has always been the presumption that governments would take negotiating parameters to the negotiating table. There is nothing new about that. The fact that the Treasurer, being asked a question by journalists at a background briefing, responded by indicating that there were parameters is nothing new. It is simply the statement of a fact.

—I ask the Minister a supplementary question. If it is nothing new, if it is normal procedure, if it is normal practice, can the Minister give us one precedent for the revelation of a precise negotiating parameter after the event of either a Premiers Conference or an international conference into which Australia has gone with a bargaining position?

—I would need, of course, to research that to find incidents of the particulars. But let me simply say that every conference that takes place is a conference in which on both sides of the table, as in legal conferences, there are negotiating parameters, and to state that is simply to state the obvious or the platitude. As I understand it, the explanation of the Cabinet's decision which was given by the Treasurer was that instructions were given by the Cabinet to achieve the maximum level of restraint and that, above everything else, the negotiation should not exceed the ceiling of real terms. To give an explanation that, 'real terms' would mean something between 9.5 per cent and 10 per cent is to state what it is quite possible to state at any time from a Cabinet decision. The world knows--
—It is to equate economic management with poker.
—It will do wonders for your bargaining position next time around.

—There have been some very interesting interjections. I want to make it perfectly clear that Premiers have repeatedly said-the transcripts of previous Premiers Conferences will reveal this-that they would object if the Commonwealth came to the table with a single line, unqualified stance on its part, that they expect the Commonwealth to come to the table with some flexibility in its parameters of negotiation and that there will be negotiation. The world knows-even Senator Evans would know-that we have been aiming, through our general economic policies, through the Review of Commonwealth Functions, through the health funding, through the whole of our policies, to get a situation in Australia in which, at the very least, cost increases in the government sector are not greater in real terms. What is new in telling the public what has been told to it a thousand times in recent weeks?

—Did the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory hear the Australian Broadcasting Commission announcement this morning of the award of a 16c an hour multi-storey site allowance which is to be added retrospectively to the 50c an hour project allowance for carpenters working on the new parliament house? Do the great height of the building and the arduous work and remote nature of the site warrant an over-award payment, for a 40-hour week, of $26.40? Furthermore, did the Minister read in today's Press that the cost of the new parliament house has doubled from the May 1978 figure of $151m to approximately $300m? Since the original cost estimate on which the decision to proceed was made has now been lost forever and has been replaced by a figure which is now wildly impractical, will the Minister terminate the program as soon as possible?

—I am unable to confirm the matters outlined by Senator MacGibbon as I have no information on the subject and I did not hear the radio report this morning. Nevertheless, I will seek some information on that matter from the Minister. As to the larger question about the continuation of the new parliament house project, I have no information which indicates that there will be a termination of the project. Indeed, I noted the remarks of the Minister on the radio the other day that the project was going ahead. Nevertheless, I will seek to get a broader report for the honourable senator as soon as possible.
—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. What is the difference between a leak and a background briefing?

—I should think that a leak would be something which is done surreptitiously and that a background briefing would be something which occurs when a journalist asks to come for a background briefing and is given one.
—Did they ask?

—My understanding is that all of the journalists asked the Treasurer whether they could come and discuss things with him. In other words, I should think that a leak would be what happens when information is planted in a sub rosa fashion with the aim of preventing anyone from tracing its source back to a particular person. The fact is that this background briefing, as I understand it, was done in a completely public sense in that a journalist asked for and was given access to a Minister and the Minister spoke frankly to the journalist. Therefore, I would think they are totally different things. It can be argued that a leak is unethical. Background briefings occur repeatedly throughout the ordinary parliamentary year, both to a total collection of journalists and to individual journalists.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. Am I to take it, then, that the Prime Minister responded to journalists when he gave his background briefing this week? Given that we agree with the Prime Minister that the public is entitled to know what the Government was prepared to grant the States-an additional one per cent-why did not the Prime Minister do it out in the open and call a Press conference?

—I think that the basic reason is the one that I have attempted to respond to here today-that everybody, the whole Federal Cabinet, would have worked upon the assumption that all governments, State and Federal, would be going to the negotiating table with negotiating parameters. That was understandable--
—That is irrelevant. Why did he not call a Press conference and have it out in the open?

—I do not think it is irrelevant. In the minds, I think, of those people-I cannot interpret their minds-would be the presumption, and I would have the presumption, that everybody, including the Press, would know that there would be negotiating parameters and therefore it was not necessary--
—I am talking about after.
—What I want to say is that the disclosure of the upper parameter came by means of a perfectly honest and frank answer--
—A leak-an organised leak.
—Order!
—What happened was that three journalists, I believe, asked individually--
—Be careful; they know what happened.

—Well, I am stating, in the presence of the Press and of this Senate, my belief. If it is not true we can soon see that and we will pursue other investigations. The fact is, as I understand it, that Mr Howard responded to a journalist and gave the journalist a frank and honest answer. I do not think that at that point the Prime Minister felt that there was any need for the public to have any further knowledge concerning it because the assumption would be that we were negotiating with parameters and that we would have moved within those parameters, as we did.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. In recent months there has been a considerable number of representations concerning the education program for infants and children. I ask: Is the Minister aware of the position regarding them? Could he advise the Senate of the current situation concerning continued funding for the Education Program for Infants and Children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator is right in suggesting that there has been a considerable number of representations in this area. If my memory serves me correctly, I think that yesterday Senator Grimes presented a petition on the subject from an unusually large number of petitioners. The honourable senator is not indicating his agreement, but that is my recollection. The early intervention projects are matters which of late have received a lot of public interest. They represent a comparatively recent development and have been supported in part by the Commonwealth and in part by the State authorities up to this time. With respect to the Education Program for Infants and Children, that is one that is conducted by Dr Clunies Ross at the Preston Institute of Technology.

ANSWER.PARA: It is proposed to maintain that at existing levels of funding, pending consideration of a report into early intervention services commissioned by the Commonwealth through the Schonell Institute. That will involve an assessment of the effectiveness of Commonwealth programs and their integration with State health, education and welfare services. It will help us to make decisions on the Commonwealth's role in this area. The report was sought by the Commonwealth because over the last few years there had been a rapid growth in early intervention services for disabled children. The children's services program of the Department of Social Security has funded some of the services. As I have previously indicated, the State governments have also taken up responsibility for many of them. It was thought by us to be appropriate for the planning of good quality services that the direction and effectiveness of the program should be assessed before too many further decisions were taken. We expect to get the report towards the end of this financial year. It has been a little delayed.

Following receipt of that report, my Department will be developing guidelines on the assessment and funding of programs of this sort, but we will have to take into account the quite complex interaction of the State and Commonwealth responsibilities in that area. Within the last few days I have extended approval for funding at the current levels to the end of this calendar year. What action is taken after that will depend upon the Schonell report and the review of that report which will be received. However, it appears that the practice of taking action early in the life of a disabled child produces very good results. I imagine that the report is likely to throw up a quite positive assessment of the value of these projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen Press reports based on a report of the official Iranian newsagency, Pars, that last Friday three persons were executed in Iran, having been convicted of charges of espionage, co-operating with the regime of the former Shah and active membership of the Baha'i organisation which apparently was described by the prosecutors as a Zionist organisation? As it appears to be evident from this report that the sole offence that those people had committed was their membership of the Baha'i religious faith and as that is a faith which is represented in this country and which appears to consist of an eminently peaceful group of people, will the Government consider making some representations of protest to the Iranian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs is aware of statements along the lines mentioned by Senator Wheeldon, and honourable senators will be aware of Government statements about the persecution of the Baha'is in Iran, including that made on 3 March by the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs in the Senate. As foreshadowed in that statement, on 9 March the Australian delegation to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights spoke strongly against Iranian violations of human rights and referred particularly to the Baha'is. On 15 March a member of the Baha'i National Council and another leading Baha'i were executed in Shiraz. The verdicts against them alleged a number of offences but also prominently cited their adherence to the Baha'i faith. Those verdicts, which were confirmed by the supreme court of Iran, indicate an intensification at the highest level of persecution of the Baha'is by the Iranian authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: Further evidence of the religious nature of this campaign was provided in late April by the aquittal, following his conversion to Islam, of a Baha'i employee of the Bank of Iran who had been charged with belonging to the deviationist Baha'i sect and with currency trafficking. The Government will continue to use available opportunities to protest in the strongest terms about the situation. I am sure that the Minister for Foreign Affairs will be interested to hear the matter raised in the way in which Senator Wheeldon did so in his question this morning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Transport recall a question I asked recently which was based on the concerns of commuter passengers flying on planes that are alleged to have airworthiness certificates from the Department of Transport based on standards which are significantly less than those applying to aircraft such as Boeing 727s, DC9s and Fokkers operated by the major airlines? In view of the recent mishaps, can the Minister give me an answer on this matter?

—On Tuesday Senator Watson asked me a question with regard to airworthiness standards for aircraft operated by commuter airlines. I have now received some further information for Senator Watson. There are differences in airworthiness standards such as those relating to aircraft performance between aircraft classified as large and those classified as small, the dividing line being the maximum takeoff weight of 5,700 kilograms. Most commuter airlines operate only small aircraft but under recently announced government policy some commuter airlines are now permitted to operate aircraft of a size coming within the classification of large. These meet the same standards as are applicable to aircraft such as DC9s or Boeing 727s. Small aircraft operated by commuter airlines are required to meet standards which are accepted internationally for that class of aircraft. But, in addition, some further operational and airworthiness requirements have been imposed by the Department of Transport, aimed at bridging the differences in standards between large and small aircraft. These additional requirements include some in respect of takeoff performance and aim at the optimum level of safety that can reasonably be required for that class of aircraft.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. It has a slightly different approach to the question asked by Senator Georges yesterday on Northern Ireland. By way of preface, I refer to the accepted fact that the political situation in Northern Ireland is compounded by its economic problems with shipbuilding and the depressed linen industry whereas the Republic of Ireland has a relative boom because of its European Economic Community dairy product sales. In that context, I was wondering whether we would be prepared to make the offer to both the United Kingdom Government and the Irish Republican Government along the lines that we would second Justice James Staples to serve on a boundaries committee to look at the boundaries, in view of the fact that, with a million and a half people, a boundaries adjustment to the Republic of Ireland could allow it easily to take additional people and leave fewer people competing for jobs and social services which is one of the root causes of the sectarian bitterness.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think any question which is put forward earnestly and which seeks to try to find some helpful solution to the problems of Northern Ireland should be treated in that regard. I so accept it. It is true that, whilst there are some 300 years of history showing various reasons for Northern Ireland's problems many of the problems have now been lost in history but the bitterness still persists. Some of the residual reasons lie in the underprivilege of some and the feelings between the haves and the have nots. Some of the difficulties arise from economic problems.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Mulvihill has raised the question of a boundaries committee and has suggested a particular individual. I am not aware of the specific virtues of the pursuit of a boundaries committee or of an absorption situation whereby southern Ireland might absorb some of Northern Ireland. I would be a very audacious person indeed if I expressed an opinion as my Scottish ancestry comes from the border close to Ireland. They married the Kennedys. I would have to be very careful in that regard. The matter of whether in general principle Australia could offer any assistance in any way is, I think, a matter which ought to be put under study. I will direct the attention of the relevant Minister to the substance of the question in both particular and principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I wonder whether the Minister would be kind enough to convey to the Prime Minister the fact that a precedent does exist. In the 1920s when this committee functioned, the British and Irish governments accepted a South African jurist named Justice Feetham. So the precedent to follow has been established. I point out to the Minister that I sent this suggestion to both the British High Commissioner and the Irish Embassy. I did not get a reply from the latter Embassy.
—I will add that supplementary information to the original question and direct it to the Minister concerned.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to the recent decision to re-form the 7th Independent Rifle Company in the Northern Territory which is comprised of volunteer reserves who carry out surveillance duties et cetera, into a unit called Norforce. Can the Minister provide the Senate with details as to the size of Norforce, the duties expected to be carried out by it, the permanency or otherwise of the unit, the date of its official formation and where the platoons of Norforce will be situated? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether any special recruiting campaigns will be conducted amongst Aboriginal people to encourage them to participate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that the North West Mobile Force, which is called Norforce, is to be formed in the Northern Territory to replace the 7th Independent Rifle Company. Norforce will utilise the present strength of the Independent Rifle Company of 212 personnel and expand to an initial target strength of 320 personnel. Norforce will be raised officially on 1 July 1981. It will be an Army Reserve unit with 40 regular soldiers. It will be permanently located in the Northern Territory with additional outstations, including the Kimberley region, being developed when practicable.

ANSWER.PARA: The role of Norforce is essentially to conduct reconnaissance and surveillance in the Northern Territory and the Kimberley region. Peacetime activities will be to mount training patrols; to develop and maintain military skills relevant to operations in north-west Australia; to acquire infrastructure and military geographic information; to employ the special skills and knowledge of the local population, including Aborigines; to provide guides and information to visiting units; and to maintain a capability to provide assistance to State, Territory and Federal authorities as directed and in accordance with existing defence policies. Special recruiting campaigns have already been conducted and these will continue. Currently 11 Aborigines have enlisted in the existing force. More Aborigines will be encouraged to join as part of further recruiting for Norforce.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs been drawn to newspaper reports that the Northern Territory Ethnic Council believes that East Timorese people are being discriminated against in Government programs for refugees? The Council claims that East Timorese people experience long delays in the processing of their applications to be reunited with their families in Australia. Will the Minister comment on these claims and indicate the number of East Timorese people who have been reunited with their families this year and the number of applications still outstanding?

—I do not have available the figures for which Senator Robertson has asked. I will have to refer his question to the Minister and obtain the figures for him. I am certainly not aware of the allegations of discrimination that have been made. I will have that matter investigated also and inform the Senate as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FOREIGN OWNERSHIP OF AUSTRALIAN RURAL PROPERTIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that Middle East interests have taken over rural properties in South Australia? Has her attention been drawn to the fact that this has resulted in gross overstocking of properties with consequent environmental degradation of the areas concerned and that it has over-inflated the value of the land because of the high prices they are prepared to pay? Is this occurring in other States? Can the Minister say whether such rural purchases by foreign interests come under the supervision of the Foreign Investment Review Board or some other Federal body? If not, does she believe that this type of transaction should be scrutinised by the Federal Government to prevent wholesale takeover of Australian farms by the Arabs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Foreign investment proposals are subject to the Foreign Takeovers Act and included in those proposals are those that involve rural land. There is no exemption limit in the Act for the examination of this matter but in normal practice what has occurred is that there has been no intervention in the case of small properties involving a consideration of less than $350,000. Beyond that limit all real estate proposals are examinable. As a general rule proposals for new agricultural or pastoral business projects involving a total investment of $5m or more are expected to have a minimum of 50 per cent Australian equity, together with 50 per cent of the voting strength on the controlling board being held by Australian interests.

ANSWER.PARA: This provision is applied flexibly to ensure that worthwhile projects are not delayed where Australian equity is not available on reasonable terms and conditions. Very few cases involve new businesses or projects. Most involve acquisitions of existing businesses. Approval for a foreign purchase is not normally given unless the Government is satisfied that Australians have been given a reasonable opportunity to buy the land in question if they wish to do so. The question asked by Senator Jessop mentioned Middle East interests. TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the briefing given by the Prime Minister. Am I to understand that what the Prime Minister did was to give information which was not to be attributed to him? In other words, was he saying: 'I am telling you these things, but do not say that I told you so'? If that is the case, was that not an organised leak? Is that not a discreditable way for a Prime Minister to behave? Is it not a fact that, if the information leaked in such a way was not favourable to the Government, then in certain situations a Prime Minister could go to the extent of denying the information which he gave and which was not allowed to be attributed to him? Would such action not be straight dishonesty on the part of the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may deal with the last part of the question first, it is palpable nonsense to suggest that any Minister or Prime Minister would proceed to have a background briefing of a journalist or journalists and later seek to deny that that had happened. The fact is that journalists are, by nature, people of integrity and have a responsibility to disclose these matters. In such a case the journalist would have said: 'This is not so'. Quite clearly the honourable senator's suggestion is palpable nonsense and should be disregarded. If there were a background briefing of one or more journalists on a matter which later became a matter of public controversy, the Minister or Prime Minister concerned would accept what he had told the journalists. No doubt a record is kept of these kinds of briefings and therefore what had been said could be easily established.

ANSWER.PARA: My understanding is that the Prime Minister had a background briefing of a journalist or journalists. He gave them information which, as I have said, one could normally expect to flow from the Premiers Conference. That briefing was certainly not in the category of a leak. I have defined my idea of a leak. That is an entirely different process. It is a process of feeding out information in a sub rosa way so that it cannot be traced back to the person who fed it out. Quite clearly, one does not have a journalist in one's office, talk to the journalist and then have it alleged that the giving of information was a leak. The two things are entirely different. I reject the thesis in Senator Georges's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Was the information to be attributed or not? What was the purpose of the device of keeping the source of the information secret?

—As I understand it, every day journalists seek background information on which to write background stories. The fact that something is non-attributable is a normal situation in the journalist's working day. I do not think that there is anything at all of particular significance in whether it was a statement reported as being the Prime Minister's or otherwise. When in fact a question was directed to Mr Howard as to how the background information got into the Press, he stated, as one would expect an honourable person to state, that he had given background information to the Press. That is a measure of the integrity and the honesty of the man.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the answers given to the supplementary questions asked by Senator Button and Senator Chipp. Is the Minister saying that the Government made three separate decisions and had three separate options on funding arrangements with the States for the Premiers Conference? Is the Minister saying that the Cabinet actually delegated to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer the right to abrogate one decision after another relating to the current discussions that went on at the Conference? In other words, can the Minister say whether Cabinet was in on the smart-Alick tactics which were subsequently adopted by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer? Further, can the Minister tell the Senate what role the Government Information Unit played in these unusual procedures relating to the Press briefings? Did the Prime Minister and the Treasurer consult the Government Information Unit or was it by-passed?

—Firstly, let me say that there were no smart-Alick tactics. The tactics carried out were the normal ethical tactics of all governments and of all leaders of governments in negotiations. Having said that, I repeat that the Premiers have repeatedly asked that the Commonwealth Government should not come to them with a fait accompli of one inflexible position, but have said repeatedly that the Government should come to them with some flexibility of negotiation. Indeed, it was in that spirit that the Cabinet looked at the decision. The Cabinet said--
—What has that to do with it? You know that has nothing to do with it.

—Mr President, if I need Senator Button's help in answering these questions I will ask for it. It, however, would not be helpful on the journey. The fact is that the Cabinet, because it has been pursuing an economic policy that has been commended internationally as well as in Australia, was seized of the fact that that same economic policy and its principles should extend to revenue sharing with the States. It gave to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer a set of negotiating parameters with the absolute maximum being the real value of the money in terms of last year's purchasing power, but with the request to them that they should seek to gain better than that in order that there should be an efficiency built into the States-the same as we have imposed on ourselves-so that the taxpayers themselves could have the benefit and so that the development of industry and commerce and of jobs in Australia should persist. The Cabinet said to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that, operating within those parameters, they could, on their own judgment, make a decision. They were given by the Cabinet a clear right to negotiate within those parameters. They were doing their job when they did that. In the course of the day there were a number of variations of position within the parameters. The final decision of 9 per cent, being close to the inflation rate, was strictly within the Cabinet guidelines and was a very proper and appropriate decision for the Conference to make. The public will acknowledge that the Government's pursuit of more efficient government is the proper thing to do.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If that were the case, what were the factors that led the Government obviously to offer option two, not option three, to the Premiers? When the Premiers did not accept the Government's original option, why did the Government, finally, then not offer the sort of money that was subsequently denied to the State Premiers and thus not have a middle position, one which has created a problem both for the Government and for the States?

—If what Senator Gietzelt is saying is that the Government should in fact have had one position-that is the upper limit that Cabinet had given it-and that the Government should have given that without any negotiation at all, there would have been no negotiation; it would have been a single line situation, and it would have been an abrogation of all the principles of negotiation and responsible government.
—We are supposed to be having co-operative federalism, are we not?

—May I therefore pose the rhetorical question: Does it simply mean that the State Premiers should have disclosed what their absolute lower limit was and indicated that they would accept their absolute lower limit? After all, if there is to be co-operative federalism and not negotiation in that regard, it must apply both ways. The fact is that there were negotiations all day. There were concessions made by the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth made its decisions within the decisions of the Cabinet. They were very proper decisions in terms of the economic future, health and prosperity of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and is supplementary to that asked by Senator Chipp. It relates to the distinction, which I accept only for the purposes of the question, which Senator Carrick made between a background briefing and a leak when he said that a background briefing occurred where a government official responded to journalists' requests for such a briefing. In the course of his answer to Senator Chipp, Senator Carrick said that initially the Prime Minister was content to leave the matter of giving a background briefing to journalists to the Treasurer, Mr Howard. Because Senator Chipp's question was not answered, I ask: When the Prime Minister formed the opinion that his view, supplementary to that of the Treasurer, should be put to journalists, did the Prime Minister invite selected journalists to hear his view? Was the initiating of this conference with journalists always with the Prime Minister?

—I just make the point that I was not aware-but I stand correction-that I said to Senator Chipp that I believed that the Prime Minister had been content to leave the matter to Mr Howard. I do not recall saying that. However, I will reply to the substance of the question. I do not know the process that went on. My understanding is that several days ago the Prime Minister, as was the case with Mr Howard, had given some background briefings. I take it that the Prime Minister did not feel that that was other than the normal, ethical way that one repeatedly provides background information to the Press. I take it that the Prime Minister found it necessary to make a public statement only when there was a public controversy as to the substance of the briefing when certain Premiers responded. Otherwise I think that the briefing has been conducted in a normal context.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister now saying that the difference between a leak and a background briefing has something to do with general ethics? Is the Minister departing from his initial answers which were to the effect that a leak can be differentiated from a background briefing on the basis that a background briefing occurs when a Minister responds to a journalist's request for such a briefing?

—I do not think that my comments to Senator Tate have changed those I made to Senator Chipp. I understand that a background briefing occurs when, whether, at the request of a journalist or a Minister, a journalist and a Minister meet and facts are given to the journalist as background and would not be denied as being given to the journalist as background.
—When you are caught.

—The interjection is: 'When you are caught'. The whole process of government could not proceed if, from day to day, governments were not willing to provide background information to journalists and the public on a whole range of matters. It is absolutely ethical for them to do that. To suggest, as I take it Senator Button does, that there should be no background briefings is to deny to the public a fund of information which, quite ethically and properly, should be made available to the public. We have done this.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS PEACEKEEPING FORCE IN THE MIDDLE EAST

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 29 April, Senator Lewis referred to comments reportedly made by Admiral Lord Hill-Norton. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) has provided the following information in response to Senator Lewis's question: The Government is aware of remarks reportedly made by Admiral Lord Hill-Norton to the effect that Australian troops should replace United Nations forces in peacekeeping operations in the Middle East. The United Nations has had long experience and involvement in peacekeeping operations in the Middle East. At present the following United Nations forces are engaged in peacekeeping operations in the Middle East: The United Nations Disengagement Observer Force, the United Nations Truce Supervisory Organisation and the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian Army officers have served for many years as military observers with UNTSO and in this capacity are associated also with the operations of the Disengagement Observer Force and the Interim Force in Lebanon. In addition, an Australian helicopter unit known as Austair was an important component of the United Nations Emergency Force whose mandate to patrol the Sinai concluded in 1979. It is therefore not accurate to identify separate options of United Nations forces and Australian troops since Australian troops have already participated with distinction in a number of Middle East and other United Nations peacekeeping operations.

The honourable senator mentioned the Zimbabwe example. The Government agrees that the Australian and other Commonwealth forces in Zimbabwe performed admirably the difficult role assigned to them. This was an exclusively Commonwealth operation. On the other hand, the situations on the West Bank, the Iran-Iraq border and the Thai-Kampuchean border all call for a very different role, even assuming that the parties concerned in these situations could agree on what that role should be. The Government agrees that United Nations peacekeeping operations play a vital role in lessening international tensions and creating conditions of stability. However, because any such operation can be mounted only with the agreement, both in principle and in detail, of the parties directly involved, there would seem to be little to be gained from raising the subject in general terms either at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting or at the United Nations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, yesterday Senator MacGibbon asked me a question through the Chair and the occupant of the Chair asked me to respond, so I took his question on notice. I now have the answer. I will seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard. It is an important matter which deals with drug abuse. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard pages 34, 35, 36 and 37 of the report on drugs presented by the Senate Select Committee on Drug Trafficking and Drug Abuse. I have shown these pages to the Chairman of Committees and he has passed them as suitable for incorporation. It is necessary to have these pages incorporated because they reinforce the statements which I made. In particular, they reveal, as I should have mentioned as part of my argument, the bromides. This would have strengthened my position.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Barbiturates. Barbiturates are the most abused prescription drugs in Australia and can induce dependence. At the time of the replacement in therapeutics of the bromides and bromureides by barbiturates as sedatives the dependence producing effect of barbiturates was not realised. There was much evidence submitted that dependence on these drugs has been largely medically induced by being too freely prescribed. There is encouraging evidence that responsible medical bodies are now taking steps to inform the medical profession that greater care should be exercised in barbiturate prescribing. When misued the barbiturate drugs induce a confusion in the mind of the abuser and it is perhaps this effect which has caused them to be one of the principal vehicles for suicide attempts. Barbiturate dependence is found mainly in the over 35 age group and more frequently in women than in men. It has been suggested to the Committee that they have been too freely used in hospitals and nursing homes as well as in the normal prescribing for patients by general practitioners. Evidence was given that in Queensland hospitals the prescribing of barbiturates has been largely replaced by nitrazepam with consequent beneficial results. This aspect of therapy should be examined by medical authorities.

With evidence available that the rate of suicide attempts is increasing in Australia, the Committee believes that a useful step would be to eliminate the opportunity for suicide by the impulsive swallowing of large numbers of barbiturate tablets. Two suggestions have been made in evidence. The first was that barbiturates should be individually wrapped in plastic or tinfoil as a deterrent to this impulsive action. A foil wrapping would have the added advantage of preventing deterioration of barbiturate tablets during storage. The second proposal was to follow a practice adopted in Japan of adding a mild emetic which in the individual tablet would be harmless but if consumed in excessive quantities would cause vomiting and therefore render the suicide attempt abortive. The Committee was unable to obtain further details of this method but suggests that it may be worth further examination by health authorities. However it does appear that individual foil wrapping of barbiturate tablets would be reasonably inexpensive and be a valuable deterrent in suicide attempts. It therefore RECOMMENDS that it should be made compulsory that barbiturate tablets be individually foil wrapped.

The bromureides-are synthetic bromides developed since the use of bromides went out of favour in medical practice because of their toxic effects. They are claimed to be sedatives with wide hypnotic action, commonly referred to as a relaxing tablet and are freely available in over-the-counter sales from chemists throughout Australia excepting in Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee has been informed that their availability is shortly to be restricted to medical precription in Tasmania. The National Health and Medical Research Council recommended some years ago that bromureides should be available throughout Australia only on medical prescription but this recommendation has not been adopted by some States.

Medical evidence given before the Committee has been scathing in its criticism of the free availability of these drugs which were claimed to be major drugs of dependence in Australia. The Committee was told that in the Melbourne area, 720,000 bromureide tablets are sold without a prescription each week, the major fraction being in inner suburbs and in industrial areas. Of their danger, an eminent medical authority said 'I think it is generally agreed that bromureides are more hazardous as far as causing straight toxic psychosis than are the barbiturates.' The Committee also received first hand evidence on the disastrous effects on the life of a family following one of its members becoming dependent on bromureides.

Only one witness defended the free availability of bromureides. In fairness it must be stated that he was a witness whose experience and professional standing must give weight to his evidence. However some of the authorities quoted by this witness in support of his arguments were found on further examination to have been quoted out of context. In the face of the overwhelming and sometimes equally eminent professional standing of other witnesses, the Committee unhesitatingly accepts the dangers of the free availability of this drug and RECOMMENDS that bromureides should be available only on medical prescription and for the same reasons as in the case as barbiturates, that bromureide tablets should be individually wrapped.

The minor analgesics are the aspirin type drugs in their various compounds. Some of them can only be obtained from pharmacies but in the main they are freely available in almost any retail establishment without restriction. Evidence was given of research which strongly indicates that the continued and excessive use of these drugs is a possible cause of the kidney disease papillary necrosis. The evidence included advice that the incidence of this complaint is extremely high in Australia, possibly fifty times as great as in other Western countries.

The high incidence of kidney disease has led to Australia becoming a leading country in the treatment of the complaint including kidney transplant operations. While leadership in this field must be applauded, the cost of such treatment as advised to the Committee in evidence is worthy of reference. A leader in this research said 'In the past two years the treatment of patients with kidney failure due to minor analgesics has cost the Australian public $500,000. Each patient with kidney failure treated with an artificial kidney costs the Australian public $5,000-$10,000 for each year of treatment'. This same witness went on to say:

'The enormous cost of continued treatment of this type for people with self-induced kidney disease which results from excessive consumption of drugs raises a very practical question as to whether drugs which can cause this type of damage should be available without restriction. The patients who develop kidney disease from excessive consumption of minor analgesic drugs take these not for any analgesic effect which they produce but as a habit. They are in fact analgesic addicts and it is very difficult to stop them from taking the analgesic drugs. They may take 50 or even 100 tablets or powders daily and often admit to taking them for the stimulating effect which they produce . . . The disease always recovers if the patient can be persuaded to stop taking drugs'.

While the research undertaken so far may not have reached a stage of providing irrefutable scientific evidence, the Committee believes that every encouragement should be given to the pursuit and extension of research in this field. The fact established are that Australia has a high incidence of kidney disease and research points strongly to this being related to the excessive consumption of minor analgesics.

Those involved in the research in this field feel so strongly on the subject that they have suggested that minor analgesics should be available only on medical prescription. Some medical witnesses supported this view and others recommended that their sale be restricted to pharmacies where at least a qualified person should be available to advise customers on their use. On the other hand witnesses representing a number of manufacturers contested both the inferences which could to date be drawn from research into kidney disease and the contention that their products should be available only on prescription or through pharmacy outlets. They maintained that the research into kidney disease was inconclusive and presented the results of a survey into the consumption of minor analgesics which indicated that 90.1 per cent of the population use minor analgesics and that 11.4 per cent are daily users.

Although not questioning the method of the survey conducted, other than that it was conducted over a short period of time and in only two areas, this isolated survey supports the view expressed in Chapter 2, that available statistic are inadequate on an Australia-wide basis. Although these witnesses were reluctant to give figures of their own production unless a similar requirement was made of all manufacturers, their written submission to the Committee stated that 'An analysis of known industry sales figures shows that the usage of mild analgesics in Australia is 0.63 tablets per person per day'. By simple calculation this reaches the staggering figure of 2,904.3 million tablets used by the Australian community in a single year.,

In assessing the considerable evidence given on the subject, the Committee concludes that greater care should be exercised by those who consume minor analgesics regularly and that their potential dangers must be made more widely known to the people. It accepts the evidence so far available that consistent and excessive use, without medical direction can be harmful but because of their widespread value for intermittent relief of minor complaints, it would be unreasonable to limit their availability to medical prescription. Nor does the Committee see any value in their sale being restricted to pharmacies only. It believes, however, that the dangers of excessive use should be clearly indicated on labels and that they should not be displayed in such a way as to encourage their purchase in impulse buying. Greater restriction should be imposed on both the form and amount of advertising of these products, window, floor and counter displays and 'specials' should not be permitted. Minor analgesics should be individually wrapped.

TALK.START.PARA: —By leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I refer to the Government's response to this Industries Assistance Commission Report which was to reject the recommendations. It is an appropriate time to note that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has a view of himself-indeed one could say a manic obsession of himself-as a disciple or a descendent of Adam Smith, Fredrich von Hayek, Ayn Rand and Milton Friedman. He sees himself as the high priest of small government, market power and of no government interference with consumer sovereignty. Last Thursday we were exposed to an orgy of self- congratulatory rhetoric on this matter. The very next day, last Friday, we saw a travesty of the Prime Ministerial rhetoric. The sordid realities displaced the sanctimony of the Fraser Government which had been revealed the day before when the Government decided to move to impose restrictions on the import of canned ham, imports which, at their peak, comprised something like 0.8 per cent of Australian pig meat production and something less than 5 per cent-about 4 per cent-of Australian canned ham production.

By that decision the Government repudiated market forces, its self-proclaimed political philosophy, the Industries Assistance Commission, consumer sovereignty which it claims ought to be sacrosanct, and its own proclaimed commitment to reducing inflation by adopting policies which will force food prices up, however marginally. It repudiated all these things and responded, as it usually does, to pressure from vested interests. In its customary grubby fashion, at what is almost a micro-level, the Fraser Government, the Prime Minister, this bearer of the standard of Adam Smith and Friedrick von Hayek, applied the power of government to protect the perceived interests of a favoured few who are clients of the Government and of the National Country Party in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean the pig producers?

—Imports which, Senator Thomas, as I have already said, amounted to less than 0.8 per cent of Australian total pig production. If Senator Thomas wishes to say that those imports threaten the interests of the pig producers, that is an interpretation and a somewhat bizarre conclusion to which he is entitled to come. What I am saying is that all of the sanctimonious rhetoric of the Fraser Government with which we were bored last Thursday was all overturned the very next day. What is really dangerous about this is that the man who is primarily responsible for it, the Prime Minister, this client, this puppet of the National Country Party, lacks the intellectual capacity to recognise the mutual exclusiveness of his own assorted manic obsessions.
