TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It will be recalled that last night during the adjournment debate I indicated my intention to seek leave to make a statement on this matter today. The reason for the statement is that, since the Premiers conference, a number of matters have been raised in the Press and considerable misunderstanding has occurred in relation to them. I therefore intend now to indicate the facts to enable a better understanding of the matter to be reached.

SPEECH.PARA: The Premiers Conference was called for May this year to discuss basically two items-revenue sharing and infrastructure financing. It was intended to get some indication in Loan Council of the thinking of both the States and the Commonwealth on the latter. The main business related to revenue sharing. It concentrated upon the fact, known to the Australian community, that the old arrangements had run out of time and that there was a need for a new set of allocations to be made to the States for the immediate future. Of course, all Premiers and the Commonwealth were aware that in the months ahead the Commonwealth Grants Commission was likely to bring down a report on relativities which could give another emphasis to the whole matter of funding. The Commonwealth came to the table at the Premiers Conference in the knowledge that it had been requested repeatedly in the past by the States not to come in a totally inflexible position and not simply to adopt one set of figures from which it would not move. Premiers had suggested that if that were the approach the matter could be dealt with by correspondence and that the correct position should be for the Commonwealth to come with flexibility of negotiation, and that is what the Commonwealth did.

The cabinet authority, under which the Commonwealth went to the Premiers Conference, was that a final decision as to the amount to be given to the States should be made at the Conference by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the light of the Cabinet's parameters and in the light of the assessment of the discussion both in terms of the economic and budgetary considerations. That in fact was done. I repeat that the Cabinet had given essential and particular parameters and had given authority to the Prime Minister and to the Treasurer to reach a point of finality of that matter following a full day's discussion. It was further stipulated that the amount in toto should not be greater than the same amount in real terms as had been provided in 1980-81, plus a sum sufficient to cover items such as urban public transport which were to be absorbed into the general revenue grants.

Leaving aside the absorption grants I point out that to understand the basis of the Commonwealth Government's stand and its approach one must look to the general state of the economy in Australia and to those steps which are necessary-and agreed upon widely-to continue to improve the economy at this vital stage. General approval of our economic policy has been indicated by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, by other countries and by economists. Our inflation rate is some two or three percentage points below those of our trading partners and we recognise that it is vital to try to retain something like that relativity. We recognise that the enormous pressures that will accompany the developmental processes in the months immediately ahead, particularly in regard to the inflow of capital and the demands upon our resources, will threaten our inflation rate.

Therefore, in the weeks and months preceding the Premiers Conference the Commonwealth set about putting its own house in order and took stringent steps to produce a state of efficiency which would permit a reduction in the size of government and thus free for use by the private sector vital resources needed for the expansion of industry and commerce and the creation of jobs. All of these are eminently respectable goals and acknowledged by economists and national leaders as being vital. The Commonwealth, through its Review of Commonwealth Functions, its review of the health scheme and its whole approach, has set out to reduce its own expenditure in order to take the heat out of inflation and borrowing rates. That has been its purpose and goal. However, the Commonwealth recognises that it cannot proceed alone, in an economic sense, to achieve those goals-that the States must accept a parallel responsibility and co-partnership in lowering the rate of inflation and taking some pressure off interest rates.

Thus, in regard to the vital segment of the revenue sharing, it was necessary to adopt the approach that whatever the quantum of revenue sharing it should not so press upon the economy as to negative the Commonwealth's policies and become inflationary in itself. In other words, the Commonwealth accepted that the states had an equal responsibility to put their own houses in order, to bring about an efficiency which would lessen the pressure imposed by government and increase the capacity of the private sector to create employment. These are eminently acceptable goals and have been acknowledged and approved as such by the community.

It was within that framework that the Cabinet decided that the absolute maximum ceiling that could be envisaged in any such negotiation would be the receipt by the States, in real money terms, of what they had received the year before. However, the Commonwealth recognised that if that were to be so there would not be exerted a pressure for the achievement of efficiency and saving and that the pressure on the rate of inflation would continue. In defining what might be meant by real money terms, the Commonwealth had in mind that the rate of inflation might be expected in the year ahead to be of the order of 9 1/2 per cent to 10 per cent. Therefore it was agreed that 9 1/2 per cent to 10 per cent would be the absolute upper limit but that the Prime Minister and Treasurer should seek to achieve something better than that in order that the States should exhibit the same good housekeeping as the Commonwealth has accepted as being necessary for itself.

That is how the Commonwealth went to the negotiating table. The negotiations ran over the full day and evening; they were intensive. A number of breaks were taken for discussions by the Premiers and by the Commonwealth. There was ample opportunity for both sides to put their views. The views of the States and of the Commonwealth were put. Indeed, there was an acknowledgment by the States that there had to be a reduction in the money given compared with that given in the past if there was to be some tackling of inflation. There was no argument that the Commonwealth in the past generally had been overgenerous in terms of the conditions that would confront the Australian community in the future. At the start the Commonwealth took the position that it would seek to achieve an 8 per cent increase in the quantum of money. As the debate emerged, it became clear that one or two States would find some difficulty because an 8 per cent increase, if broken up, would give one or two States less than 8 per cent. So the Commonwealth suggested that we might look at bringing the increase for all States up to 8 per cent. That meant that certain amounts had to be added to the South Australian, Tasmanian and Victorian shares so that every State had 8 per cent. That amount was an additional $27m which had the overall effect of the quantum being, from memory, about 8.4 per cent, with no State getting less than 8 per cent. That again was a matter for vigorous discussion.

The discussion having gone over the morning and the afternoon, it was adjourned for dinner. There was a lengthy discussion following dinner between the Prime Minster, the Treasurer and the five other Ministers who had special reasons for being present. The States' arguments were taken into account and it was agreed that the Commonwealth's pre-absorption offer-that is, the offer regarding tax sharing-should be lifted to 9 per cent. That meant that, together with the absorption items, the increase would be 10.1 per cent. An increase of 9 per cent, which would be compared with the total real value of money in the range from 9.5 per cent to 10 per cent, was considered a respectable response to the request from the States for adequate money to enable them, with some minimum efficiency, to pursue their tasks and to put their house in order, as the Commonwealth did. The Commonwealth indicated that 9 per cent would be its final negotiating position, and it was.

The Premiers went away and, of course, the normal discussion occurred in the Press. Each of the parties went to the table with negotiating parameters. The Premiers did not disclose their parameters, nor were they asked to. Everybody understood that everybody round that table had those parameters and everybody understood that the community outside would know that. The States would have known that the intention of the Commonwealth would be to get the best bargain it could for the Australian community in terms of the best economic policies and that the Commonwealth was striving, within those parameters, to get agreement on a lower section of the parameters. That would have been understood; it would have been taken for granted. Any suggestion of surprise today would involve a failure to understand the normal negotiations at the table.

Following that, there occurred the normal discussions with the Press. The Premiers no doubt pursued numerous backgrounding sessions with the Press, as well as direct Press conferences. There is no doubt in the world that they will have given background information to the Press, as they have done enormously in the past. It is equally known that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer provided background information. I said during Question Time today that it is the normal process of governments in every country in the world, whether State or Federal and of whatever political faith, to provide the Press throughout the day with background information. The Press itself understands that from time to time it needs and uses what is called unattributable information, not because there is anything wrong in attributing it but because the very nature of the story is such that it is a background story and not just one man's statement on that story. So background briefing has occurred beyond any doubt at all at both State and Federal levels.

Without any question of secrecy, as I understand it, the Treasurer was approached by a number of journalists. I think he agreed to talk with them on his own. It is perfectly plain to anyone who understands the process that that matter could become public property and would not be in any way unethical. No one who understands the Treasurer would attempt in any way to impugn his integrity and honesty. He is a man of great frankness and great courage in presenting the honest facts to the Australian people. In these briefings, as in all matters, his behaviour has been impeccable, as has that of the Prime Minister.

Normally the limits of the parameters would not have been raised because it would have been generally assumed that the parameters existed and that the Commonwealth would have settled below its maximum. That is the normal situation. That would be fully understood. But, as I understand it, a journalist, or some journalists, asked both Mr Howard and Mr Fraser whether the Commonwealth has been too lenient, the important point being whether the Commonwealth, having set very stringent standards for itself with regard to its own behaviour, had relented or weakened in the journey with the States. That was a question of considerable importance because it recognised that it was vital for the States to set the same stringencies as the Commonwealth. Mr Howard indicated clearly that that was not so, that we had negotiated to a ceiling of real values but that we had been able to achieve something less than that, although the 9 per cent increase represented a very respectable amount for the Premiers.

The fact is that there has been some reaction from one or more of the Premiers on this matter. Mr Howard has said that perhaps it was an error of judgment on his part to have commented in the detail that he did. In so saying, he was not saying that the error of judgment was one of ethics or impropriety. As I understand it, he was saying that, although the Premiers would well know and suspect that the Commonwealth's final offer was below the ceiling, there may have been some sensitivities about a public revelation of that and that it might have been better left unsaid, although fully understood by everyone involved an any negotiations. So the Treasurer, being the man he is, made those comments.

The suggestion has been made that there is some impropriety in telling the Press the substance of some Cabinet decisions. I cannot comprehend how such a long bow could have been drawn. The fact is that, whilst Cabinet discussions remain confidential and whilst some Cabinet decisions that have a long term consequence have to remain confidential, it is normal, where no necessary confidentiality is imposed, for the Minister concerned to have the full capacity, based on his judgment, to indicate Cabinet decisions. All of us, day by day, are indicating Cabinet decisions to the public. Certainly there was no impropriety in indicating that decision. It is very proper for us to tell the Australian people, as I have done, how the Commonwealth Government viewed the economy, how the Commonwealth Government, with very great solicitude for the employment prospects of Australians for the future, seeks to keep the economy in excellent shape and to create more jobs, and how the Commonwealth Government intends that the States should work in copartnership in that regard. The Commonwealth Government has set particular parameters. Therefore, I would reject unequivocally any suggestion that there has been any impropriety as regards a Cabinet decision.

As to the fact that some three or four journalists became party to the particulars, the Government would have presumed that all the community would have accepted the existence of parameters at the State and Federal levels and that the Government would have worked to keep the final position below the ceiling. Therefore, what was stated by the Treasurer in response to a question-it would not otherwise have been stated-was a presumption that would be drawn by all. They are the simple facts of the case. At a Premiers Conference there is always an attempt by the Premiers to get the maximum amount of money they can get. There is never an occasion on which the Premiers will publicly admit that they are happy with the result. At the conclusion of every Premiers Conference held in Australia statements have been made by the various Premiers that they have been short-changed. Nevetheless, they privately acknowledge that in the years that have passed they have been given a generosity in funding by way of revenue grants which would be quite wrong in the general concept of the rigidities and stringencies needed for the future if we are to have prosperity and the employment prospects.

Of course, there will be the normal response of the Premiers that they have not received enough. Of course, they have a completely valid right to go into the Conference and fight like Kilkenny cats to get as much as they can. Equally, the Commonwealth has an absolute moral responsibility to go into the Premiers Conference and bring about the result it thinks is best for the Australian people. I repeat that a 9 per cent result, based against a prediction of 9.5 per cent to 10 per cent, inflation rate, is a result that the States are quite competent to cope with and and it is quite competent for them to do that without having to apply anything like the efficiency measures that the Commonwealth has applied. The achievement and the adoption of that would have provided the kind of copartnership that was essential. It is interesting that virtually every correspondent and every editorial in Australia has acknowledged the need for the Commonwealth to achieve a finality with the States which would create a stringency upon them in terms of good housekeeping.

As to the journey after that result, the negotiations having been carried out in the strictly correct way, there is nothing in the background briefings or the comments that are in any way unethical or improper. The contrary is true. It is true, I suppose, that no political leader would like to read in the newspapers that, in fact, he was not capable of getting all that a Cabinet ceiling might have enabled him to get. Every Premier in his heart of hearts knew that that was highly unlikely. Every Premier must have known when he left the conference table that the Commonwealth would have sought to get, within the centre means of those parameters, the best for the people of Australia. Indeed, that was done. I believe that this issue has been blown out of all proportion. In fact, the Commonwealth, by its actions both in setting its own house in order in the previous weeks and by it achievements at the Premiers Conference, has done something that will be applauded world-wide as being the best for the Australian people in terms of good economics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I am underwhelmed, as some say, by the blandness of the statement by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick). Last night, when we were having something of a debate about this matter, Senator Carrick came into the Senate and apologised for not being in the chamber earlier. He said:

I intend to schedule for tomorrow morning a statement and a debate on this matter. Mr President, in ordinary procedures, that will allow what I understand the Opposition has been seeking tonight and that is what our intention is.

Of course, what we were seeking last night was some explanation of the conduct of various Ministers and Press secretaries of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in standing over journalists in this place. We were seeking an explanation of the conduct of and the inconsistencies between two Ministers in particular about a set of facts which occurred earlier this week. It is not much comfort for us for the Minister to come into the Senate and tell us about the Government's economic management-the 'Play it again, Sam' tune-and the great savings which have been imposed on the community as a result of the Premiers Conference.

Firstly, I shall test Senator Carrick's fundamental proposition, which goes to the heart of this matter. His fundamental proposition in the Senate this morning is that everybody in Australia-all the sophisticates in Australia, except members of the Australian Labor Party Opposition and people like that-know that when Premiers meet with the Commonwealth Government they each have a negotiating position-a parameter, as it were-for the purposes of discussion. What has now been revealed, of course, is that the parameter of the Federal Government in dealing with the Premiers was greater than the amount which the Premiers were in fact granted. Let us change the terminology for a minute and forget the Premiers, none of whom may be particularly attractive figures to everybody. Let us remember that we are talking about the taxpayers' money and we are talking about the delivery of community and government services to the people of Australia. As Senator Bjelke-Petersen knows, it is not as though the Premiers will stick the money in their own pockets. The money which Queensland gets is used by the Queensland Government to provide services to the people of Queensland. We are not just talking about the Premiers.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going too far now.
—I am sorry. I believe I have taken it too far. The point is that we are talking about taxpayers' money and the way that this Government handles taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me test Senator Carrick's fundamental proposition by asking some questions. This is the Parliament of Australia which, according to all traditions of the Parliament of Australia, is entitled to know as well as anybody in this country what the facts are about government decisions. What would have happened if I had come into the Senate on Tuesday after the Premiers Conference and asked Senator Carrick: 'What were the parameters which the Commonwealth Government had in its negotiations with the Premiers'?' If I had asked Senator Carrick that on Tuesday morning, what would he have said? Does anybody in the Senate believe that he would have said anything other than: 'No, I am sorry, you cannot have that information. That is a matter confidential to the Cabinet'? Would he have said anything else? Has he ever said anything else in this chamber when asked questions of that kind? That is what he would have said on Tuesday. Senators and members of this Parliament would not be entitled to know, but journalists selected for background briefings by Malcolm Fraser would be entitled to know. That is the point of it all.

Let me take another example of Senator Carrick's glibness about this question of how the sophisticates of Australian society know that they all have negotiating positions at the Premiers Conference. Let us take this in another context and assume that the Commonwealth Government is involved in negotiations concerning wages with its employees and the Commonwealth Government offers its employees a wage rise of $10 a week. Let us presume that the day after the wage rise has been announced a senior public servant goes to the newspapers and says: 'They are mugs, those unions, they could have had $12 if they had pressed harder'. Supposing a senior public servant did that a couple of days later. What would any self-respecting government do to him? It would sack him. That is what should be done to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) of this country because they did exactly the same thing as the public servant in the hypothetical case I have put forward. There would be uproar in this country if that occurred in relation to an industrial relations situation.

As I said earlier this sort of information is not even available to members of this Parliament but it is available to the people whom the Prime Minister of this country selects to tell about it in a context of boasting about how tough and smart he is. That is the context in which Cabinet secrets, denied to members of this Parliament, are given to the public of Australia. It is called backgrounding. It is not acknowledged. The Prime Minister is not doing it. A senior government official made the information available. The new pseudonym for the Prime Minister for Australia is 'a senior government official'. I remember a year ago when the Budget was leaked. According to some people that was leaked by a senior government official. We wonder which senior government official leaked the Budget last year to Laurie Oakes. Was it the same senior government official who leaked information on this occasion?

The Government's claim that we all ought to understand that we do have negotiating positions, that Premiers have negotiating positions, that the Commonwealth Government has negotiating positions-it is an in-club thing-and that we understand the rules, is nonsense. That sort of information, and the sort of information to which I have referred about the parameters of Commonwealth Government decisions in the offer that was to be made to the Premiers, is available to selected people chosen by the Prime Minister, but it is not available to the Parliament of Australia. I am prepared to go along with the suggestion that it ought not to be available. It is not available to people other than those selected journalists.

Senator Carrick came in here this morning floating that proposition blandly. He made no response to the suggestions which were made last night. I understand that he is the only Minister to speak in this debate. He is to be supported by the resident Cicero, Senator Puplick, who will no doubt seek to close the debate, but no other Ministers are coming in here to defend the Prime Minister. They have got sick of defending the Prime Minister. Fourteen Ministers in the Fraser Government have gone now. Why should anybody else such as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) put his head on the block. He might be next. Senator Puplick, a senator who will not even be here after June, has been selected as the sacrificial lamb to contribute to this debate at a later stage. Senator Carrick talks blandly about this issue as if nobody had been upset by it. He actually said in what was I think the most classic patronising remark that I have ever heard him make-I have heard him make plenty-that some people were sensitive about this issue. I tell him that Sir Charles Court is sensitive about it. I want to tell the Senate what Sir Charles Court had to say. He said:
Apart from producing flick knives or Molotov cocktails, I don't know what these anonymous 'officials' are supposed to mean about being tougher.
He is referring to the anonymous officials, the senior government source, which we now know to be the pseudonym for the Prime Minister of our country. Sir Charles Court went on to say:
Premiers conferences are not a game of bluff poker in which the biggest cheat gets the most money.

I apologise for using that word, Mr President. I was ruled out of order for using it last night but the Premier of the largest State of Australia has used it in the same context. He is reported as saying:
Premiers conferences are not a game of bluff poker in which the biggest cheat gets the most money.

They do involve some pretty tough negotiations, but if the Commonwealth is sitting around chortling about stealing even more money from the States than it thought it could get away with we have reached the absolute nadir of Federation in Australia.

We have heard lots of rhetoric about the Premiers Conference in this place. Whatever one likes to say about it and whatever one's political view, the Premiers Conference is the CHOGM, the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, of this little banana republic of Australia. It is a meeting of heads of government and it is a meeting of six significant figures with the heads of the Commonwealth Government. Let us imagine what will happen at the next Premiers Conference-the most important conference in terms of federalism in this country, in terms of what this Government is pleased to call co-operative federalism. It is the most important conference in terms of heads of government in this country. For example, at the next Premiers Conference the Commonwealth Government will say: 'We have got 10 per cent of tax reimbursements for you'. The Premiers will all say: 'But that cannot be true. That is what you told us last time. You told us there was a maximum figure last time. After you told us that it was a maximum figure you went and told selected journalists something quite different, that that was not the maximum figure at all'. What will happen at the next Premiers Conference?

It goes to the whole question of the credibility of the system of government in our country. It goes to the whole system of whether we can trust the Prime Minister of Australia, whether the Premiers can trust him or whether he is pulling the wool over the eyes of the leaders of the six governments of Australia as he has been pulling the wool over the eyes of the ordinary people of Australia for the last five years. That is the question of government which is involved, and the integrity of the system of government in Australia stands on the answer to that question.

Can the Premiers any longer trust the Prime Minister? What will happen at the next Premiers Conference? What will be said in answer to the Commonwealth's offer by the Premiers. They will say: 'We cannot trust you'. Even if they say, 'Finally we are prepared to trust you in relation to the answer you have given,' the next question the Premiers of Australia will ask is, 'When we get out of here are you going to go to journalists and tell them that we are a pack of mugs, that we do not know what we are doing and that we are being outsmarted by you, Mr Fraser'. That is the question the Premiers will ask. They will ask: 'Are you going to go to journalists and tell them that on this occasion'?

When referring to the comments made by Sir Charles Court, Senator Carrick blandly and patronisingly said: 'Sir Charles Court is sensitive about the issue'. By God he is sensitive about the issue and so is every other Premier. Anybody who is concerned about the integrity and the ongoing processes of government in this country ought to be sensitive about it. The only people who are not sensitive about it are those wafflers on the Government side of the chamber who come in here and make bland, waffley statements about important issues confronting this country. They are not sensitive about this issue. Their only sensitivity is keeping on that side of the chamber. They will do anything to justify that position but it is not in the interests of good government in this country.

The negotiating position of the Premiers in the future is placed in an extraordinary situation. The negotiating position of future Commonwealth governments, not just this Government, is placed in jeopardy because of the action in leaking a Cabinet decision-the action of the Prime Minister and the action of the Treasurer of our country. That is what in fact happened. What it means is the end of Premiers Conferences in terms of sensible, frank and honest dealings between the parties. To that extent it is an indication of the utterly cynical view of government of the Prime Minister of this country. We have reached a low point in the political history of Australia.

Mr President, I do not wish to go into the question of economic management involved. The question of economic management involved is that this Government rides on the seat of its pants. Its attitude is: 'Give or take $70m, we can do this or that'. It takes $70m from the people of this country but it does not give them $70m. It is ludicrous to adopt the position which Senator Carrick has adopted, that this is a respectable attitude for a government to have. Senator Carrick this morning tried to suggest that Treasurer Howard is an honourable boy. He leaked information to selected members of the Press after the--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was backgrounding, not leaking.

—I apologise to Senator Chipp. Mr Howard backgrounds, which Senator Carrick explains to us is an art form of sophisticated government. He backgrounded the Commonwealth's position on the Premiers Conference to selected journalists. It was only afterwards, in our view and on a correct statement of the facts, when he got caught, that he started to come clean on the whole issue. It was not, as Senator Carrick said, that he rushed out and said that he had done the wrong thing. He did that later on, only when he got caught. Senator Carrick seems to be trying to make the point that all these activities by the two Ministers were perfectly legitimate in that they were explaining to the Australian people what the Commonwealth's position was at the Premiers Conference. If it was perfectly legitimate for two Ministers-the Treasurer and the Prime Minister-to behave in this way, why did they try to hide what they had done? Why did they try to hide what they did when they got caught? Why did Mr David Barnett, presumably with the authority of the Prime Minister of Australia-our country-stand over journalists of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, telling them: 'That program is not to be run'? Treasurer Howard and the Prime Minister had already made that program. Why did Mr Barnett stand over journalists in the national broadcasting system of our country saying: 'You must not run the interviews which we have given to you. You are no longer allowed to do that.' Did he not say later last night that the careers of two journalists involved would be finished as a result of running interviews which Mr Fraser and Mr Howard had given to the Australian Broadcasting Commission?
—Who said that?
—Mr Barnett, the same man whom Piggy Muldoon-I am sorry Mr President; I mean the Prime Minister of New Zealand-accuses of being a disruptive influence in the Australian Government, said that.
—And Arthur Lloyd.

—I am sorry; and Mr Lloyd. That is what happened. Senator Carrick has said: 'It is all above board. There is no need for worry'. If that is so, why did the Treasurer and the Prime Minister go to extreme lengths to try to hide from the people of Australia and the members of this Parliament what they had done? The answer is that they were caught. That is why they did it. They wanted to stop the truth from getting out. So much for integrity in government under the Fraser Government. Mr Malcolm Fraser is the Prime Minister who sacked Senator Withers with the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: We had no doubt that our first and foremost responsibility was the maintenance of the high standards of propriety set and maintained by this Government.

Senator Withers should get a knighthood tomorrow. Phil Lynch stuck to his position and he got one. Senator Withers should get a knighthood tomorrow for his standards of propriety. His standards of propriety are absolutely impeccable compared with those displayed yesterday by the Prime Minister of Australia. The Prime Minister, when he sacked Senator Withers, went on to say:
The community rightly demands a high standard from the Ministers of government.

The high standard that the Prime Minister demands of his Ministers is that they put their heads on the block. The tough Prime Minister of Australia said to Treasurer Howard: 'Excuse me, you take the rap. I am not going to take it'. He has said the same thing to Andrew Peacock on a number of occasions. That is the standard of Ministers which is required by the Prime Minister. He went on to say:
The judgments on Ministers are more exacting and sometimes more harsh than the judgments which might be passed on those outside the sphere of public life.
In relation to Senator Withers he said:
If these standards were not upheld, the people's confidence in government-a confidence which is fundamental to the Australian democracy-would be undermined.

No incident in the history of this shoddy Government has so much undermined the system of government in Australia as what happened earlier this week in relation to the Premiers Conference. The Premiers are rightfully enraged. This Parliament is properly concerned about the standards which have been applied. In answer to questions we have heard all this stuff about Cabinet solidarity, Cabinet secrecy and so on. The person euphemistically described as a senior government official is now on record as being a breaker of Cabinet solidarity and a 'backgrounder', to use Senator Carrick's word, of Cabinet decisions. Do the other members of the Cabinet really realise that fact? When are the Ministers in this Government going to face up to the fact that the Cabinet which is said by the Press and others to leak like a sieve has only one hole? We know what that is. It is the senior government official referred to by journalists in all their reports on background information. Another issue is involved. The Prime Minister, amongst others, is often on record as saying that governments should be accountable to the people. This Government is the least accountable to the people of any government in the history of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—Does Senator Teague recall that Mr Andrew Peacock used to run a group called the mushroom club in Canberra? It had only a few members in those days but now it has an enormous number of members and Senator Teague is one of them. He is in the mushroom club. The great mushroom cloud of what Andrew Peacock said 14 days ago hangs over his head and over the head of this Government. Everything that has been revealed in the last two days points out that he is right. If Prime Minister Fraser is prepared to background or leak-whatever expression he uses-confidential Cabinet decisions in the way in which he did this week, who is to deny Andrew Peacock the claim that that is what happened in his case? Who is to deny Andrew Peacock the veracity of that claim? We cannot deny it, because the Prime Minister and Treasurer Howard did leak information. Treasurer Howard glibly described the action as an error of judgment, not only on his part but also on the part of the Prime Minister. That is the problem that Senator Teague has.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me come to the question of accountability which concerns the honourable senator. I say that the Prime Minister of this country does not make himself accountable because, apart from last night and once last week when he was under considerable pressure and perhaps could not make decisions in the way in which he usually makes them, for five years he has not given a Press conference in which he has made himself available for questioning by journalists. Yesterday, when he did give a Press conference, and journalists asked him questions, he said: 'Oh no, I am not going to answer that. This Press conference was to deal with this question and this question'. He was effectively saying: 'I answer only those questions the details of which I have before I give a Press conference, and I will not talk to you about anything else'. Is that accountability to the public? After all, we talk about the Press as the Fourth Estate, the guardian of civil liberties, the medium whereby information is provided to the Australian public. This Prime Minister is not accountable at all. He prefers the background briefing or the leak to people who, he thinks, might favour him a bit rather than a frank open discussion with the Press. He has never had such a discussion. That is the sort of accountability the Prime Minister deals in.

Another dreadful thing about the way in which this matter is handled is the manner in which the Prime Minister, having been found out, seeks to blame yet another Minister. Last night we saw Treasurer Howard on television, a pathetic figure, saying: 'Look, it was my fault--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mea culpa.

—'Mea culpa'-as the scholar at the back tells me. 'I did it', said Treasurer Howard. When he is pressed a bit, he says: 'Well, look, it is not really that I did it, that it is entirely my fault. But I did it first. The Prime Minister did it second. I am first in sequence in leaking confidential Cabinet information. I am first cab off the rank, so I should take the rap'. But, in the last dying moments of his Press conference, he could not stand it any longer, and he said: 'Perhaps you ought to ask the Prime Minister a few questions about this too'. That was an act of gross disloyalty by Treasurer Howard, If I might say so. He should have taken the rap quietly and gone the way of the 14 other Ministers who have disappeared from the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This is another example of the Prime Minister acting without the authority of his Cabinet, acting in a way which is detrimental to the system of Government in this country, acting in a way which betrays the trust in the whole system of government, and acting in a way which, in my view, creates disastrous situations for future Press conferences. It is all done in an atmosphere of no genuine accountability at all. It is all done in an atmosphere, I say to Senator Teague, when we talk about accountability, in which a member of the Prime Minister's staff goes to the national broadcasting service and says: 'Do not run that interview that you have been given'. That is the Prime Minister's view of accountability. That is censorship which is characteristic of the government of Idi Amin and a dozen governments in South America, and, sadly, it is becoming increasingly characteristic of our Government in Australia. That is a tragedy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has that been independently verified? Are you sure of that?
—You get up and deny it.
—Are you sure?

—I am quite sure of it, absolutely sure. This statement which has been brought down by the Minister is a charade. It does not go to the essential issues of government about which the Senate and the Parliament ought to be concerned, and about which all Government members ought to be concerned. They do not know what goes on in the Fraser Government. They do not know what the gang of four decides about these issues. It is time that they did, if we are to have an effective Parliament and, it is to be hoped, an effective democracy in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate arises out of a controversy which surfaced yesterday, a controversy which does not come up as a result of actions by the Opposition, or as a result of actions of the Press. It arises because of the dubious behaviour, the dishonest behaviour, of the Treasurer (Mr Howard), the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Prime Minister's Press Secretary, Mr David Barnett, and, I suggest, to that dubious behaviour can be added the behaviour of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) in this place today.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night on the adjournment we attempted to start a debate on this matter. We attempted to introduce this matter so that we could get a sensible and proper statement from the Government as to the behaviour of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer for the previous two hours on television and on the media in general in this country. We were told by Senator Carrick that he would make an opportunity for a statement to be made and for a full discussion to take place in the Senate today. 'That could not be fairer', said Senator Carrick.

He promised us a full discussion. He promised us a ministerial statement. But what have we had in fact? We have had the Leader of the Government in this place, the Prime Minister's representative in this place, making an ad lib statement. There is no written statement. This is the first time that I can remember when a statement of which notice has been given by a Minister has been produced in this manner. We have had a homily on the Government's economic policy and, towards the end of the statement, a little discussion on the fact that flexible negotiations take place at Premiers Conferences and, at the end of it, a little statement saying that the Treasurer, Mr Howard, is an honourable man and that when he was found out he admitted what he had done. We were told that we would have a full discussion on this matter. In fact we have had one Cabinet Minister making a relatively unprepared statement in this place. We are told that two members of the Opposition will be allowed to speak-that is, Senator Button and myself-and then Senator Puplick will be moved in to move the gag and to stop further discussion. That, I suggest, is not full discussion, and the statement is not a reasonable statement in view of what has happened.

What has happened in this controversy results from the deception of the gentlemen concerned, from the deception of Treasurer Howard, the Prime Minister, and particularly Press Secretary David Barnett. What has happened is that the Parliament and the people of this country have been treated with contempt by all of those people and, as Senator Button has said, this demonstrates a lack of accountability by those gentlemen, by those leading spokesmen of the Cabinet and of the Government of this country, in their handling of this matter.

What happened, I think, should be clearly put on record. As has been admitted by all concerned, including Senator Carrick, the Treasurer, Mr Howard, and the Prime Minister himself, gave what are called background briefings, and in those background briefings to selected journalists they spilled the beans and told what the upper level of the parameter was, what the upper limit of payments to the States was which the Cabinet would allow them to negotiate on. They did not tell the Parliament of this country. I am not suggesting that they necessarily should have, but if they told anyone they should have told the parliament of this country. They did not tell the public in a public Press statement. They let this information out in a non-attributable background briefing.

The Premiers became annoyed. Premier Court called for the resignation of the Treasurer-that is Premier Court who is of the same Party as the Treasurer, and an alleged supporter of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. The Press then went to the Treasurer, first of all, and said: 'Tell us about this. Let us know about this briefing. Let us know whether these reports in the paper are true'. The Treasurer did not immediately admit what he had done. He refused to answer questions, and, at his first Press conference, he talked all around the question. The same thing happened at the first Press conference of the Prime Minister. He refused to answer questions, and anyone who saw him on television last night would realise how angry he was that these questions were brought up.

Senator Carrick's suggestion that Treasurer Howard is an honourable man and that, when confronted with the situation, he admitted what he had done, is quite wrong. He did not admit what he had done. He called a Press conference later and admitted what he had done. One can imagine what happened. One can imagine that he went out and contacted the Prime Minister to see what they would do. One can imagine that the conversation between them would be like the conversation which is reported to have occurred between Senator Withers and the Prime Minister just before Senator Withers' demise from the Cabinet in this place. The Prime Minister is alleged to have said to Senator Withers: 'You are in trouble', and Senator Withers replied, 'We are in trouble'.

Obviously the Prime Minister and the Treasurer got together and sought means to get out of this situation. It was then that the Treasurer had his Press conference and admitted to the Press of this country, and through the Press to the rest of us, that he had leaked this information to the Press at a background briefing. As Senator Button said, if anyone in this Parliament had stood up on Tuesday after the Premiers Conference and asked Senator Carrick or Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who represents the Treasurer, what were the parameters under which the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) negotiated matters at the Premiers Conference he would not have received an answer. We would have been told that that was confidential Cabinet information.

If anyone should get an answer, if anyone should be given that information, certainly it should be the people of this country, through the elected representatives of this country. To sneak into a dark room, as one newspaper put it, and, over a glass of whisky, spill the beans is quite wrong and is contempt of this Parliament. For the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to deny at the first Press conference that this had been done and then, when the pressure was on, to run away and cook up a plan between them and later to admit it is bad enough. But for their representatives to have the gall to come into this place and say that Treasurer Howard is an honourable man and that he admitted that he was wrong as soon as he was detected is even worse. He admitted he was wrong because he had no alternative.

Firstly, Treasurer Howard gave the information in a background briefing. Secondly, he attempted to deceive the Press when he was asked about it. When pressed further at an interview he admitted to what he had done. Attempts were made-I will come to that in a minute-to have the interview in which he made that admission gagged and stopped from being broadcast over the networks of this country. Yesterday afternoon Prime Minister Fraser refused to answer questions on the subject. He became extremely annoyed that anyone would have the cheek to suggest that he had taken part in leaking this information. Later, when he had to admit that it had happened, he had the gall to try to bluff this way out of the situation by saying that it was part of his belief that there should be freedom of information in this country. He said:
The Press should be happy with what we have done because we need freedom of information.

We do need freedom of information but information of this sort should be given publicly and openly, and above all it should be given to this Parliament. But it would not have been given to this Parliament or to anybody in this country if the circumstances which arose out of that background briefing had not arisen.

Then, probably the most sinister character of all, the Press Secretary of the Prime Minister, David Barnett, M.B.E., arrived on the scene. When David Barnett found out what was going on he-obviously with the approval of the Prime Minister and probably under the instructions of the Prime Minister-stormed around to the Press Gallery of this Parliament and into the Australian Broadcasting Commission office, where he told the head of staff that the interview with Treasurer Howard should not go to air, should not be published and should not be broadcast for the information of the people of this country. He threatened two journalists that their jobs would be on the line if they proceeded with the story in the way they were proceeding. He then tried to pressure other people in the Press Gallery to change their stories and to alter their line.

This is not the first time that Mr Barnett has done this. He is notorious for behaving in this way. It is not the first time that he has behaved in a dishonest way. Prime Minister Muldoon of New Zealand has complained on many occasions about the behaviour of that character, particularly at overseas conferences. For example, he described incidents in London, Lusaka and Zambia where Mr Barnett leaked premature or inaccurate information to the Press to promote his Prime Minister against Mr Muldoon and Mrs Thatcher. Mr Muldoon described the anger that he and Mrs Thatcher felt at the behaviour of Mr David Barnett.

Mr Muldoon admitted that he did not think much of the Australian Prime Minister's Press office, that it has a bad habit of trying to big note its Prime Minister by putting down other leaders, that it uses inaccurate information, and that it leaked information to the Press and promoted in the Press violent rows between Mr Muldoon and Mr Fraser. As Mr Muldoon said, this does not help international relations and this does not help to settle international disputes. We have this man, who holds a responsible position, a senior position and a powerful position in this country, behaving like a second class thug, walking around to the Press Gallery and threatening journalists. He has done so not only in this country but also overseas. Last night's episode was disgraceful and no one-I am certain Senator Puplick, who will follow me in this debate-will be able to deny that that happened. I challenge anyone on the Government side and I challenge Mr Barnett to deny that what I have said happened last night.

We have a sad story of deception by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. We have a sad story of contempt of this Parliament and of the State Premiers by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. We have an example of the lack of accountability by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to this Parliament, which is something we have experienced so often in the past. It is no wonder that there was a controversy and that people on both sides of this Parliament and people who are concerned about democratic government and proper government in this country are concerned. That is why we sought and still seek a full and proper debate on this matter. That is why we sought a proper statement to this Parliament about what happened-not an ad hoc statement about the Government's economic policies, not an ad hoc statement of the kind that we have heard over and over again in this place about the need for restraint and the need for the States to pull their horns in.

Firstly, we want to know why the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of this country are allowed to deceive the Premiers and to treat the economic affairs of this country like a game of poker, as one Premier, Sir Charles Court, described it. Secondly, we want to know why the Government is going on like two-bit poker players, bluffing the Premiers and then, unable to hide its glee, running to the Press and leaking what the Government had done; that is, to quote the words of Premier Court, cheat the Premiers. These Ministers, unable to hide their glee, had to go, as one person put it, and chortle at the Premiers and sneer at the competence and ability of the Premiers to conduct their affairs, and to do so without reporting to this Parliament, without any responsibility to this Parliament and in utter contempt of this Parliament.

Senator Carrick's statement is quite unsatisfactory. We need a proper explanation of what goes on. After such a proper statement, I suggest that we should then question whether the Treasurer is fit to be Treasurer of this country, whether the Prime Minister is fit to be the Prime Minister of this country and whether a person who behaves in the way Mr Barnett behaved on this occasion and on other occasions should have a senior position in which he is responsible to the Prime Minister of this country. We have not had that. Obviously we will not have a satisfactory debate here today. We have registered our concern about and contempt for the manner in which the Government is conducting itself. We will continue to do so. No good can come out of this for the Government or the country. It is a sad day when this Parliament is treated in this manner. I implore the Government to allow a proper debate and to produce a proper statement on this affair in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: -After a great deal of sound and fury the mountain opposite has laboured and managed to bring forth in this debate two white mice, neither of whom, of course, is present in the chamber now. (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying, after all of the exertions, the Opposition mountain, having laboured has brought forward nothing more than two white mice neither of whom is yet present in the chamber despite the ringing of the bells for a quorum. Those two white mice to whom I propose to refer in some detail have attempted to put up a case in this debate which is simply unsustainable. I am happy with the remarks of Senator Button who referred to me as some sort of resident Cicero because on this occasion I am happy to play that role to the petty Cataline that he seems to be determined to play today in concocting this conspiracy of nonsense. The speech that we have heard from Senator Button which was really nothing more than a farrago of irrelevancies, a catalogue of innuendos, assertions and baseless accusations. It was followed by a complaining litany from Senator Grimes who managed to add absolutely nothing to what Senator Button had said and then he complained that he did not have enough time in the debate for a proper discussion to take place.

It seems to me that four issues arise specifically from what has been said in the Senate and what has been said in the general debate over this issue. I believe they are: Exactly what are the facts and the relevance of the issue, and the public disclosure of the Commonwealth position. Secondly, what, if anything, is to be concluded about the public announcement of what the Commonwealth's negotiating position was after the conclusion of the Premiers Conference? Thirdly, is there any validity in the accusations that the Premiers were somehow shortchanged or indeed duped or deceived? Finally, was the statement issued by the Treasurer by way of the background briefing, although in his view with hindsight an error of judgment, in any way improper?

The first of those issues relates to the facts. Quite clearly, as Senator Carrick has said and as has been indicated in the other place, prior to the Premiers Conference the Cabinet took a series of decisions about the parameters of the financial offer that the Government was prepared to make to the States and imposed some sort of upper limit, apparently a level of about 10 per cent, plus the additional funding needed for absorption purposes. Like all negotiations, that was the extreme position and clearly the Commonwealth was going to put to the Prermies a going-in offer substantially below the level which it had set as a maximum. We know that the initial offer to the Premiers was about 8 per cent plus the absorption grant money. By a process of negotiation this was eventually raised to 9 per cent plus the absorption money. Criticisms were made after the conclusion of the Conference. They were made in the Press. They were made on a number of occasions. That criticism was that the Commonwealth was somehow not fair dinkum about the whole attitide of reduction of government expenditure, that the Commonwealth had been overly generous with the States and that it was not attempting to apply to the States in respect of the works and the functions that the States were to take up, the same sort of rigorous scrutiny that the Commonwealth had applied to its own requirements and future programs. Indeed, the Treasurer, Mr Howard, at his Press conference alluded to this. He said:
I explained to you--
That is, in response to a question-

That the purpose of doing it was in the context that I thought there were suggestions that the Commonwealth had perhaps not lived up to its rhetoric of earlier times of the previous week, but in the context of those suggestions this type of comment-this type of backgrounding-was appropriate.

In other words, he was setting down quite clearly that the Commonwealth had sought to bring to the Premiers Conference and to the grants made to the Premiers a degree of scrutiny and a degree of financial rigour along the lines that it had already adopted for its own purposes over the last couple of months and which had been most recently announced in the Review of Commonwealth Functions. The background briefing was therefore to provide the facts and to indicate that the Commonwealth in fact had not been bullied into a position, coerced into a position or slipped into a position which was beyond a reasonable statement of its own financial limitations and its own financial policies and to indicate that the Treasurer in fact had given this information in response to questions that were asked of him and, in a way, that was appropriate to the questions that were asked of him. It is certainly true that some of the State Premiers in their initial responses-Sir Charles Court in particular-have taken objection to what they have seen portrayed in the Press as an attempt to indicate that they, as a group of hardened, political professionals, were somehow unable to cope with the Machiavellian designs of the Federal Treasurer and the Prime Minister in coming to grips with Commonwealth-State financial relations.

The second question I posed was: What flows from the decision? What does the fact that the background briefing was given actually mean in terms of the real impact on either Government policy or on the way in which government is conducted in Australia? I suggest absolutely nothing can be drawn as a direct inference from the way in which this matter was handled. Absolutely nothing can be drawn along the lines that Senator Button and Senator Grimes sought to do. It certainly was not intended by any of the persons involved as some sort of insult to the Premiers. It certainly was not intended as some sort of 'laughing up their sleeves' at the naivety of the Premiers or crowing over the alleged ability of the Commonwealth to put one over the Premiers. I do not think anybody could seriously entertain that that was in the mind of the Federal Treasurer or the Prime Minister who after all have to deal with the State governments and the State Premiers on an ongoing basis, year by year. It certainly is not possible to draw any inferences from the behaviour of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer along the lines that Senator Button did in his speech.

The third point I raised was the question of whether the Premiers had somehow been short-changed, whether the Premiers had somehow been done out of money which was rightfully and properly theirs. The answer to that is: Far from it. The treatment which the States have received from the Commonwealth Government in the last five or six years has been the most generous treatment that they have ever received. Many people on this side of the Parliament believe that from time to time the treatment has been overly generous. While the Commonwealth has been making the necessary adjustments and taking the necessary steps to restrain its own expenditure, to restrain the growth in the number of its own public servants and the extent to which it is required to raise taxes and charges from the Australian community at large, the States have not shouldered their fair degree of the national economic burden and have not sought to undertake the same sorts of rigours in their own expenditure and their own behaviour that the Commonwealth has made a feature of its expenditure and behaviour in the last couple of years.

Despite that, the States have still been treated extremely generously. In recent years they have been receiving in the vicinity of a 40 per cent return of personal income tax taken in Australia. The figure in the next couple of years will be 38 point something per cent of the total personal tax take. A new formula is to be entered into in which the States will have access not only to personal income tax but also to the whole tax revenue pool of the Commonwealth. Their own instrumentalities, their own local governments, which are creations of State governments and are not the direct responsibility of the Federal Government, have been provided with a source of income. They have been provided with a figure which has grown steadily from 1 1/4 per cent to 2 per cent of personal tax takes. That is not only a direct subvention to local government but also a considerable easing of the burden that the States would otherwise have to shoulder for the financing of their own creations.

To that extent, the argument cannot be put forward that somehow the States have been short-changed; that somehow they should have got $70m more. They cannot argue that they were entitled to that amount when in fact what they were entitled to was to come to a Premiers conference in Canberra and to negotiate with the Commonwealth Government over a figure which ended up being accepted by both sides and which clearly, as has been indicated, was amended in the course of the discussions to increase the actual amount of revenue that the States were to get. The increase was above what the Commonwealth went in with as a negotiating position but, by the way in which the conference eventually came to a final decision, was below the upper limit which the Treasurer and the Prime Minister had been charged by the Cabinet simply not to exceed. They had not been charged by the Cabinet to ensure that the States got that particular amount of money. They had been charged by the Cabinet to ensure that that was the upper limit beyond which no offer could be made. It is part of the normal negotiating process, whether it be between individuals, companies or States, for any party to go in with an opening offer and to know itself its absolute limit, its absolute maximum offer, and to try to find some figure which falls within those two parameters as the eventual figure on which things will be settled.

I turn to the speech made by Senator Button. I want to indicate a number of instances in which Senator Button was either critical of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer or tried to put forward arguments which he believes somehow reflect on the way in which this matter was handled. The first totally irrelevant type of argument that he put forward was that if this sort of leak had been made by a senior public servant in discussing wage negotiations that senior public servant would automatically have been fired. The answer to that is: Yes, indeed, that senior public servant should automatically have been fired. The problem is that Senator Button clearly does not distinguish or does not seek to distinguish between the position of a person who is a public servant and the position of a person who is a member of the Cabinet or, indeed, who is Prime Minister and therefore whose entitlement to make public Cabinet decisions is not a matter of dispute whereas the position of a public servant making public the decisions of Cabinet is of an entirely different quality and character. 'We are entitled', said Senator Button, 'to get the facts'. Because the facts are put on the record by the Treasurer in this regard the Opposition considers that that is somehow suddenly a source of criticism. In other words, quite clearly, members of the Opposition want it both ways: They want the facts but they do not want the Treasurer to give out the facts. Senator Button cannot put both of those arguments at the same time.

During the whole course of Senator Button's speech he sought deliberately to avoid-he said that he was deliberately avoiding it-any discussion about what exactly it was that the Premiers and the Commonwealth were negotiating about, what exactly the underlying economic policies were that had brought about a situation in which the Commonwealth clearly was going to insist that there be reductions in expenditure and in which the Commonwealth clearly was not going to be in a position of offering straight out, or automatically, a maximum figure for the States so that they would be able to continue on their merry way without any thought of restraint or responsibility in their own financial administrations.
Senator Button, in response to Senator Teague, made some comments about accountability. This Government, he said, was not an accountable government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither is it.

—The acid test of accountability, Senator McLaren, is accountability to the Australian electorate. This Government has submitted itself three times to that acid test. On three straight occasions the accountability of this Government to the Australian people has been tested and on each of those three occasions the Australian public has responded by returning this Government with record majorities. Yet this is supposed to be a government which is not accountable. Clearly, it is accountable and has been at every one of the last three elections. It is accountable and it makes itself accountable in this Parliament where it is tested and continues to come through all of the tests which are put against it by the Opposition. It has come through in this place and in the other place without a mark being left on it by the feeble attempts of the Opposition to make some capital out of passing events which it seeks to blow up into matters of monumental importance. As I said, Senator Grimes who followed for the Opposition in the debate complained that there was not enough time for the debate and then in the time that he took proceeded to add absolutely nothing to what his Senate leader had already said; he indicated quite clearly just how seriously the Labor Party wanted to take this debate. It was simply making a point again and again in the hope that it would be like something in Alice in Wonderland: If something is said often enough somebody will be foolish enough to believe that it is true.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth point that I indicated was clearly central to what has been put before this chamber is the question of whether a briefing, a set of statements or information given by senior Ministers to people on the details of a Commonwealth position were in some sense of the term improper. It is quite clear, I think, from the statements that have been made that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer clearly had the authority of the Cabinet to release details of Cabinet decisions which had been taken and which related to their areas of responsibility. The Prime Minister, in his own Press conference, said at one stage:

We did not go beyond real terms, and in this world in which freedom of information is so important, why should the Press or anyone worry about the fact that the Treasurer, in consultation with myself-and I last night, made it plain that we had been given that kind of authority,--
That is the authority of the Cabinet to make known Cabinet decisions-
that we should not go beyond real terms, and the final position was somewhat less than that, but the decision made it plain that the final judgment was to be made on the day.

Similarly, Mr Howard, in his statement from which I have already quoted, indicates quite clearly what the background to it was. Indeed, in an earlier statement that he put out on the matter, Mr Howard said:

As to the allegation of breaching confidentiality the Prime Minister has taken the line that he and I plainly have authority to discuss a Cabinet Decision in an area of our own responsibility and this quite plainly was such an area.

The nonsense proposition, if this quoted statement is denied, is that somehow Cabinet decisions are not for public release. In other words, the Cabinet will make decision and in no circumstances and through the mouth of no Minister will anybody in the public arena be told what those Cabinet decisions are. Presumably, Cabinet will make decisions, will pass them on to some public servant or to somebody for administration, but that in no circumstances and at no time should the public be told what those Cabinet decisions are. Clearly, unless Cabinet decides that for certain reasons of security or, for instance, because the premature disclosure of a particular Cabinet position would be disadvantageous to the nation, to the national economy, to the national interest or to the national defence, that Cabinet decision is not released at that time but the decision is made public at an appropriate time. Obviously, any other Cabinet decision is going to be released at some point, presumably by the appropriate Minister. In terms of Commonwealth-State relations in the Premiers Conference, clearly the responsible Ministers are the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. They had the responsibility and the authority to make clear those decisions and those determinations which they thought appropriate to make clear to the Parliament, to the Press, to the Premiers or to anybody else.

Was the particular decision improper in that it benefited somebody at the expense of somebody else, was it improper in that it breached vital national interests, was it improper in that it implied some breach of Cabinet solidarity or of collective responsibility of the Cabinet? Clearly, the answer to all those questions is no. It was an exposure, in terms of public policy, of a Cabinet decision which was made in the public interest. Since Cabinet is supposed to and does under this Government operate to make decisions in the public interest, it is not surprising that from time to time the public is told what the bases of those Cabinet decisions are. Clearly, the Prime Minister specifically has addressed his mind to this matter and has said something about it in his Press conference. I propose to repeat those words. When challenged on the basis that perhaps this was a breach of Cabinet confidentiality, the Prime Minister said:

. . . what you are aiming at is a total absurdity. Because, if the Cabinet makes a decision, which is relevant to the Treasurer's authority and to my authority in relation to a Premiers' Conference, obviously either of us or both of us are entitled to make that decision public, and to suggest that we are not entitled to make a Cabinet decision public and to suggest that the Treasurer is not entitled to make a Cabinet decision public, which is within his area of responsibility is total absurdity--
He goes on to say:

It is not a question of leaking any information to the Press. It is a question of a Cabinet decision having been taken, and of a Cabinet decision having been made public, and there is nothing wrong with a Cabinet decision being made public.

That is quite clearly a statement of the facts as they pertain in this case. We come to the question of the extent to which in a debate about the way in which Cabinet government is conducted in Australia, the Australian Labor Party is in any position to make a comment about the effective conduct of Cabinet in Australia. During the course of the debate some time ago on a ministerial resignation down the other end, the Minister for Defence was on his feet. His words were salutary in respect of the way in which proper Cabinet government is conducted. The Minister for Defence, referring to previous Cabinet practices under Labor, said:

How many honourable members who sit opposite today and who have served in the two governments led by Mr Whitlam would be prepared to give to this House the instances of when they were defeated in the Cabinet and, either on their own account or through the assistance of some other colleague, took the issue into the Caucus. I notice that the honourable member for Capricornia--
that is Dr Everingham-

is standing up. There it is! There is the very perversion of the principle that I propose to enunciate. Without shame and without inhibition, constantly and coarsely, the Australian Labor Party has put political principle and regarded it as a mere coquetry of political prostitution.

That is precisely the attitude which the Australian Labor Party takes towards the operation of Cabinet government in Australia. We know full well the numerous and documented instances-whether it was Thursday, 13 September 1973 when Minister Bryant had to take into Caucus a special resolution to try to overturn Cabinet policy on interest rates on housing loans, or whether it was 20 May 1975 when poor old Moss Cass, in one of those momumental fights with Rex Connor, was stood on his ear by the Prime Minister who described him as inefficient and hopeless as a Minister and had to take the Fraser Island decision for the rape of Fraser Island back into the Caucus where he was eventually rolled by 42 votes to 41 votes. We know the way in which Ministers in the Labor Government used to lock themselves in their offices like naughty little boys who were caught smoking in the toilets and who refused to be ejected from their offices because they were about to be sacked. We know the way in which the sorry sagas of Cairns, Connors, Cass, Khemlani and Crean were paraded through the Parliament as an example of what the Opposition believes is the style of Cabinet government appropriate in Australia today. We know the extent to which the Australian Labor Party in this debate has revealed its paucity as an Opposition.
