—It is very much in gear, Minister, and I would like yours to be equally in gear as this debate proceeds and for the Minister also to be given an opportunity to answer on behalf of his government as to the extraordinary sequence of events in which it has been involved. I simply put it to you, Mr President, that a number of questions which have been raised by recent events need answering. It has been suggested that in the last few days this Government has done a number of wrong things. It has been suggested that it was wrong of the Government to deceive the Premiers in the first place as to the extent of the Commonwealth's financial capacity. That question needs to be resolved, as a matter of urgent necessity, by the Senate. It has been suggested that it is wrong for the Commonwealth, having deceived the Premiers in this way, to crow about it; that that is a classic demonstration of political immaturity. It has been suggested further--

—I rise on a point of order. Surely Senator Evans is now canvassing the issues involved in the earlier debate. He claims that he is making out a different case in favour of the suspension of the Standing Orders, but I believe that he is canvassing issues raised earlier and consequently is not addressing himself to the motion to suspend the Standing Orders.

—I am not canvassing the issues; I am simply listing the matters which need canvassing, which need further subtantive debate. I am not now speaking to any of the substantive issues. I will deal with those with loving care, attention and detail if we get to the stage of substantive debate in a few minutes time. I am simply offering a shopping list of issues which remain unresolved and must be addressed by the Senate if we are sensibly to tackle the problems of the nation, which have been added to so spectacularly by the events of the last few days.
—Senator Evans, as you well know, in moving for the suspension of Standing Orders you can speak only to why they should be suspended and not to any substance.

—That is right. I am not claiming that the third issue is that it is wrong for the Government to appear to have intimidated and to have covered up its original denial. I am simply saying that one of the issues which this Parliament needs to be satisfied about concerns the facts about, the circumstances surrounding and the justification for that alleged intimidation.

SPEECH.PARA: The remaining issue which it is very obvious this Parliament needs to tackle and to debate is the suggestion that it has been wrong to treat the conventional notion of Cabinet confidentiality as the kind of plaything and vehicle for self-aggrandisement for the Prime Minister which seems to have been the case, it has been argued, in this instance. In particular we need to debate the suggestion that it has been a sickening exercise in cant and hypocrisy for the Government to invoke the principles of freedom of information in justification for what it has been doing. Those are the sorts of things which need, as a matter of urgent necessity, to be further debated, as do a number of other claims that are being made around this Parliament and around this nation today in the light of recent events. It is being claimed that this Government engages in confident thuggery when it is on top but, by contrast, is engaged in no more than cowardly dissimulation whenever its deceits are revealed.

It is being suggested equally that this is a government of opportunism for which no principle is too sacred for it to stand on its head if the political advantage of the moment seems to justify it. It is being suggested all around this nation, and it needs to be further debated in this Parliament, that this is a government of hypocrisy from which no single statement can be accepted at face value any more by anyone. That has been learnt by the Parliament. Equally it appears, and it has been claimed, that the Premiers can no longer take at face value the assertions of this Government. It is being suggested around this Parliament and around this nation-and it needs answering-that this is a government of incompetence which not only is manifestly incapable of administering policy and programs but also is so incompetent that it treats everyone else collectively as being as big a mug as it is in terms of the strategy that engages it. It is being suggested-this is another and the last of the particular matters I wish to refer to-that this is a government of self-immolation bent on a path of self-destruction, the key Ministers in which are unable to maintain even the pretence or appearance of a facade of unity. Those are matters which the ministerial statement has raised for the attention of the Parliament. Those are matters which this Parliament must deal with.

The final reason I suggest that there is a pressing necessity for this Parliament to debate further the ministerial statement is that later in the program today we are scheduled to have a resumption of the freedom of information debate. At the moment the Parliament is being left in a state of total confusion as to exactly what the Government's position is on freedom of information as a result of these developments. The question that needs to be understood and resolved before we can proceed with that freedom of information debate is whether this Government is simply being dissimulating in its commitment to freedom of information. There is a question of whether it has been engaged in sickening cant and hypocrisy, as I said, in relying on and invoking freedom of information principles in support of its stand on the leaking of the Premiers Conference negotiation parameters. Alternatively, there is the possibility that there has been a change of heart on the part of this Government and that there is a wholly new conviction and commitment to freedom of information principles involved in what the Prime Minister, Treasurer Howard and Senator Carrick were saying today.

It may be that there has been some kind of Paul-like conversion on the road to some Damascus as far as freedom of information is concerned. If that is true, if the Government has changed its position on freedom of information, it will change the whole context of the debate which is scheduled to take place later today. If the Government has changed its position on freedom of information in the way which appears from the course of action that has been taken and the justification for that action, we do not want to waste time stumbling around the foothills of that problem when it comes to the debate later this afternoon. There are mountains there to be climbed. It is clear that the whole course of resistance to amendments to that Bill which the Government has proposed has now been completely changed, if that is indeed the proper interpretation of what has taken place. Clearly that dilemma as to whether there has been a change of heart in the Government's attitude is another matter that needs to be resolved in the context of further debate of this ministerial statement. For all those reasons, I suggest it is clear that there are many matters remaining for the Government to answer. Many charges remain totally unanswered by anything that Senator Puplick or any other spokesman for the Government has said. For those reasons, the debate ought to be resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion, for two reasons. I shall stick to why we should suspend Standing Orders and will not engage in a repetition of the debate we had earlier today. The first reason is that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) should be permitted to honour the promise he made last evening that there would be a ministerial statement and a full discussion. That has not been carried out. Therefore, the Government has no alternative but to support its leader so that he may be given the opportunity to honour the undertaking he gave to the Senate last night that there would be a full discussion here today.

SPEECH.PARA: The other reason concerns the severity of the Matter. Having received from South Australia both telegrams and today's issue of the Adelaide Advertiser, I can see the deplorable situation that that State is in as a result of the allocation of money at the Premiers Conference. One notable thing is that Mr Tonkin, who has been one of the greatest supporters of the Fraser Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —He backed his policies to the hilt during the election.

—He backed his policies to the hilt. Mr Tonkin has restricted the Public Service in South Australia in line with the propaganda of the Federal Government and has imposed greater sacrifices on the South Australian community than possibly any other State government in Australia, but today is very critical of the treatment that has been dealt out to him. In the stop press of the Advertiser he is reported as saying that he has lost complete confidence in future negotiations with what is termed responsible government.
—Who said that?

—David Tonkin, the Premier of South Australia. When he told South Australians that there would be a further cut in public works in South Australia he told them, amongst other things, that capital works concerning kindergartens and hospitals would be cut back. We find today that legal aid services are to be withdrawn from prison officers in South Australia who are facing a crisis as the result of the appointment of a royal commission in that State.

SPEECH.PARA: When serious allegations were made against prison officers in South Australia, the Premier appointed a judge from Western Australia as a royal commissioner to consider allegations as to the conduct of prisons in South Australia. One after another prisoners have made serious allegations against prison officers. Some of those allegations could have been proved untruthful in cross-examination by counsel representing the prison officers. In future those common workmen who today operate in the prisons are to be left without any legal representation, the victims of whatever lies and perfidy may be directed against them by prisoners in those institutions. Judging by the statements that have been made, we believe that there has been a robbery of some $70m. Surely we should sort out this matter and have a full discussion. In view of Mr Tonkin's remarks on his lack of confidence in negotiations between responsible governments, surely we must restore this Government's recognition as a responsible organisation for the purpose of seeing that at least South Australian Premiers can have an idea of fair play and decency in this matter. There is a lot I want to say-I believe I was on the speaker's list before it was terminated-on the negotiations. I shall seek that opportunity and ask for decency on the part of the Government to honour its undertaking of last night and to give us the opportunity for further debate on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the debate continuing on the motion that the Senate take note of the paper.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

Senator Harradine is correct in his objections to the removal of General Business from today's program, because there are important matters to be debated. SPEECH.PARA: For the whole of this session we have gone for days in this place without adequate debate of important legislation. It is absolutely unnecessary either to abandon General Business or to extend the sittings, as has been telegraphed to us will happen at the end of this session. TALK.START.PARA: -I record my opposition to the motion moved by Senator Messner who is the Minister in charge of the chamber. Once again, we will lose the opportunity to deal with General Business because Government Business will take precedence. As my colleague and deputy leader, Senator Grimes, has pointed out, the Government is in complete disarray. Yesterday when the proceedings were being broadcast we witnessed a complete vacuum for at least five minutes because the Government could not get its act together. If my colleague had not called a quorum to get it off the hook it would have been in worse trouble. Now we find ourselves in this position. The Government cannot run the affairs of state, it cannot run this place, and now we are to lose the time for General Business tonight in favour of Government Business. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I record my protest in regard to this matter. I am somewhat in sympathy with the remarks expressed by Senator Harradine. Obviously, the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill, the Freedom of Information Bill and the Excise Tariff Amemdment Bill are of more importance to the Government than the Order of the day which relates to the International Year of Disabled persons. That is given second consideration by the Government. I think our concern about the attitude the Government is taking should be noted in this, the International Year of Disabled Persons.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one point that I make frequently and which I want to make again today. There are so few opportunities for back benchers to ventilate their concerns in this place. On Thursday nights matters of importance to back benchers are brought up for discussion and a government reaction can be obtained. Some of those matters raised do bring a result. But once again, that right is to be taken away from us. The rights of back benchers no longer exists under this Government. It keeps encroaching upon the right of back benchers to have matters of General Business discussed in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with the remarks which have been made but the Australian Democrats will not oppose this motion by forcing it to a division. When the Government Whip asked Senator Mason and me how we felt about dispensing with the General Business debate tonight, reluctantly we said that we would agree, notwithstanding the fact that we would be the greatest sufferers because of this action. Of the first eight items on the Notice Paper, Senator Mason and I would have enjoyed speaking on at least four of them. They are listed with us. The reason we reluctantly agreed to allow Government Business to take precedence of General Business is that allegedly there is so much very important legislation to come through this chamber before the Senate rises. For weeks now we have been dithering about with the Freedom of Information Bill. I made a judgment that it is more important to the Government to get the Freedom of Information Bill through this place than private senators' rights which, as Senator Cavanagh quite properly says, are also important. If we do not follow this course near the end of session the Government, with its weight of numbers, will force this legislation through and we will get a hotch potch on important legislation such as the Freedom of Information legislation. I understand that there are something like 40 Bills of some importance to be passed before the Parliament rises at the end of this session. Already it is mooted that the Senate will have to sit at least two more weeks. I will just name a few of the proposed changes to legislation. —I thank Senator McClelland for his interjection. I acknowledge it so that it can be included in Hansard as a contribution to what I am saying. I do say this to the Government, with as much good will as I can muster: Yesterday, as Senator Grimes said, it took the Government something like five or six hours extra to get a relatively simple amendment through this chamber because there were enough senators, not only on this side of the chamber, but also on the Government side, who felt fairly strongly about a Bill the ramifications of which were to be thrust on 14 million Australians. Back benchers in this place consider General Business on Thursday night to be important to them. Much of the debates in the rest of the week is taken up by the front bench on both sides of the House. I voice strong objection to the sudden taking away of General Business night from back benchers. There was no indication early in the week that this would happen but now we face this proposition. The Australian Democrats will suffer considerably because of this proposition. —You cannot leave this place as far as I am concerned. I will tell the Whip on you.
—I did not hear the interjection but I will acknowledge it so that I can read it in Hansard tomorrow. If I take offence at it I will raise the matter then.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the seriousness of the situation, we cannot continue to play around with the Notice Paper in the way that we are playing around with it at the moment. TALK.START.PARA: —Has she got a sister?
—I beg your pardon?
—Has she got a sister?
—I am too easily diverted while I am on my feet. I should know better.
—You cannot handle that one, can you?

—No, I cannot. I am not quick enough. I am getting slow. When I first came to this place I used to fight for my rights, and I was quick on my feet and quick of mind. But I am slowing up now and I cannot deal with the interjections any more. I should not respond. I should just plough on regardless and I am ploughing on regardless to make the point that I hope that our right to a General Business night will not be treated in this cavalier fashion next week, the week after and perhaps for the next four weeks. In the meantime, since the Australian Democrats have accepted the proposition and the Opposition does not have the numbers, we will just have to suffer it, but we protest.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Overall the function of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill 1981 is to set up a new structure for industrial research and development incentive schemes. Its effectiveness will depend on the level of funding which the Commonwealth Government gives to industrial research and development. My remarks will be brief. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add ', but the Senate-
(1) Expresses its concern at-
(a) the low level of Government investment in research and development compared to other technologically advanced nations;
(b) the failure of the Government to encourage significant private sector investment in research and development;
(c) the low level of Australian innovation as measured by the number of patients taken out each year by Australian individuals and companies;
(d) the failure of the Government to stimulate Australian innovation in electronics, biotechnology and other high technology industries, and
(e) Australia's disadvantageous position in relation to technology transfer;

(2) Condemns the Government for losing national control over significant industries based on high levels of research and development, including motor manufacturing, electronics, the computer industry and petrochemicals; and

(3) Rejects those parts of the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions (the 'Lynch Committee') which eliminate or downgrade Commonwealth instrumentalities concerned with the collection, dissemination and application of information about high technology in industry, thereby reducing Australia's fight back capacity in high technology areas'.

What we are saying in this amendment to the second reading is something that has been said by members of this Parliament of all political persuasions in some of those esoteric debates that we have about policy in relation to science and technology and which mean nothing in terms of government action. We say that Australia's performance in relation to research and technology is a poor one. Because of the structure of the Australian economy, if the industries about which we are concerned are to be developed, in the latter years of this century, much will depend on the attention to which this Parliament, the Government and industry gives to questions of technological innovation, research and development. That is the essence of what is being said.

I said earlier that the Bill sets up a structure for industrial research and development incentives. Its effectiveness depends on adequate Commonwealth funding. I am not making a partisan criticism when I say that the level of Commonwealth funding is inadequate. Yesterday, in another speech, I referred to an answer given in 1976 by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) when the Department of Productivity was set up. An important point in the answer given by the Prime Minister in 1976 was that questions of technological innovation, technological transfer, research and development are issues which affect the long term future of this country. As I said yesterday the wicked thing about the deliberations of the razor gang is that they are not concerned with the long term future of this country. They are concerned with immediate perceptions about political advantage and ideology. They are not concerned with long term questions. The same general comment can be made in the context of this Bill.

The Bill allows funding of research associations formed by firms in an industry to get together to form an association for research on industry problems. That is a good thing. This was advocated by the Birch Independent Inquiry into the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. We regard it as a good thing and are glad that the Government has acceded to that recommendation of the Birch Committee. We commend the Government for that action.

I refer briefly to what the Government has done in the area of science and technology, quite apart from the cuts which were announced at the end of last week. Of the 18 bodies which were abolished by the so called razor gang, 11 belonged to the Department of Science and Technology. I am not saying that all of these bodies were necessary or that it is necessary to retain all of those 11 bodies. They included important areas of industrial and technological research and development such as the Information Technology Council, the Advisory Committee on International Scientific and Technological Activities and the Australian Inventions Advisory Committee. The Department of Foreign Affairs will no longer have a science adviser who may get information from abroad which is to our national advantage. I do not know-probably no members of Parliament including the razor gang know-how those bodies worked and how effective they were. But that is not the point. The important point is that, if these functions of Government are abandoned, inevitably Government will become less well informed and less efficient. That is something which again relates to time scales in politics. The long term problems of this country will not be addressed. Instead short term political gains will be, as usual, the priority of the Fraser Government. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack), in his second reading speech, said:
Funding has risen from $14m in 1977-78 to $54m in 1980-81-nearly a four-fold rise within three years, despite the need for continuing expenditure restraints.

That is said in the context of the second reading speech on this Bill but one should look at it in conjunction with the report of the so called razor gang which announced cuts. This shows the level of co-ordination in this Government. We have a second reading speech of this kind which boasts about fund increases, at the same time that committee of Ministers-not the gang of four, but the razor gang-introduces cuts across the board in the science and technology portfolio. In the second reading speech the Attorney-General, in justification for increased funding in this area, said:

The rationale for government assistance rests on the proposition that there are disparities between the private and national returns from research and development expenditure. The market does not provide enough incentives for firms to undertake research and development.
I might say that the market in Australia is a bit soft on these issues. The Attorney-General went on to say:

The result is a national under-investment in industrial research and development and a tendency for firms to concentrate on relatively short-term industrial research and development. The fundamental purpose of the program is to correct this market failure.
The Opposition applauds what the Attorney-General said in that respect. He went on to say:

Against this background, the Government has decided that, in future, an industrial research and development project will be supported only where it involves a substantial degree of risk or where a firm is unable to gain enough of the profits generated by the industrial research and development to justify the project.

That is an interesting statement. So much for the cliched ideology of the private sector taking up the slack. The private sector will not take up the slack in industrial research and development unless the everlasting arm of the Commonwealth Government is there to support it. That is an important point to recognise in relation to this statement. The Minister went on to say:
To compensate for inflation as well as to strengthen the incentive to firms to undertake the industrial research and development, the Government proposes to increase ceilings . . .

The Attorney-General indicated the proposed increased ceilings in grants which are to be made available. What happened to all that economic rationalism in the Attorney-General's speech when the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee made its report? The report not only cuts back areas of science and technology research but also cut back Commonwealth funding for defence science, research and development. As I have said, Australia has a poor record in research and development. This reflects a lack of commitment from government. There is a very high degree of overseas ownership of the high technological industries we do have. The research and development is done overseas. The product of that research and development becomes the property of those foreign companies. This is true of the motor car industry, and the mining industry. It is true of a low and now shrinking educational base in Australia. The Australian motor car industry and the Australian mining industry import technology. A number of tables are available indicating the shrinking educational base in Australia compared with the position of other countries which are relevant in relation to research. By Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development standards we have a low educational base in the 15 to 19-year-old group. For example, educational base in Australia for that age group is below that of Greece and Ireland, not countries with which we always want to be compared. There is a correlation between a high educational standard at the secondary and post-secondary levels and a healthy economy. There is a correlation between those educational standards and a high standard of living and economic growth. Australia is well down that list. The Australian Labor Party is the party in this country that has by far the greatest commitment to raising educational standards across the board.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from what I have said by way of making general points which are always important in a discussion of science and technology, I would like to make one or two other points. It is our very great regret that, because of ideological factors which have possessed bodies such as the so-called razor gang, decisions about important matters relating to science and technology are no longer being made with a view to the long term future of this country. They are being made in a short-sighted way and they are being made in a way which reflects, as I have said on previous occasions, concern not about the future of Australia and its industrial base but about the forthcoming election and things of that kind.

SPEECH.PARA: We of the Opposition generally support the Bill. The point we make is that the future of science and technology policy in this country would be better assured if the Government took into account the matters raised in the amendment which I have moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this Bill because it is certainly a move in the right direction. I could be critical and say that the Bill does not go far enough in that direction. I may comment on that later. The implications of technological change for Australia are immense. We have to encourage Australian industry to be innovative and to take new initiatives in this important area of industrial research and development. I notice that the Bill provides for another five-year program for industrial research and development incentives. I also note that one or two expert committees are mentioned in the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Recently the Government has been urged to stimulate industrial research and development by a number of expert committees including the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia-CITCA-and the Australian Science and Technology Council-ASTEC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it include a reference to your Committee?

—I was a little disappointed to note that the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment was not given some sort of honourable mention in the speech. Honourable senators will recall that in June 1979 the Committee, of which I am Chairman, presented a report to the Senate. I regret very much that the Government has not yet responded to that report. We made something like 61 recommendations. I will refer to one or two of them in a moment to remind honourable senators of the significance that the Committee placed on policy determination in this area. I think the instructions of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to his Ministers that they should respond to parliamentary reports of this character within six months is highly commendable. I regret very much that almost two years have been allowed to pass and we are yet to see the Government response to this very significant document which has received the acclaim of the Institution of Engineers of Australia, the vice-chancellor's committee and other significant organisations throughout Australia who make the point that this document is worthy of government action and favourable consideration. I noted the other day that the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Thomson, had called for more investment in industrial research. The Minister was speaking at the opening of EMI's computer-aided design bureau in Melbourne. An article in the Australian Financial Review of 28 April states:

SPEECH.PARA: Private enterprise was still not investing enough in industrial research and development, the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Thomson, said yesterday.
The prospects and possibilities for Australian industry opening up through the application of computer technology, he said, were profound and exciting.
'But they will only be realised if we adopt technology faster and integrate it better than our competitors', he said.

That is a true statement. I think it is very important for the Government to provide more incentives for industry to invest in this important area of industrial research and development. I felt constrained to reply to that particular Press comment and on behalf of the Committee I issued a Press release which, unfortunately, I do not think saw the light of day in the media. However, for the benefit of the Senate I would like just to read the comments that I have made. The release states:

Senator Don Jessop (Liberal, SA), the Chairman of the Senate Science and the Environment Committee, today agreed with the statement made on Monday, 27 April, by the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr D. Thomson, that private enterprise in Australia was still not investing enough in industrial research and development.
However, Senator Jessop said that the Commonwealth Government could do more to encourage Australian business to devote additional resources to industrial research and development.

The Science and Environment Committee in its report 'Industrial Research and Development in Australia' (tabled on 6 June 1979) found that Commonwealth legislation intended to stimulate industrial research and development in Australia had so far failed in their purpose.
Government incentives for IR & D were nowhere near commensurate with need nor did they bear any other than incidental relation to national objectives.

In its report the Committee drew attention to the decline in IR & D in Australia. Between 1973-74 and 1976-77, gross expenditure on research and development in Australia, as a percentage of gross domestic product fell from 1.29 per cent to 0.97 per cent, a reduction of 20 per cent. No other OECD country showed so great a decline. This decline was due primarily to a fall-off in private enterprise R & D which dropped drastically from 35 per cent of total expenditure in 1973-74 to only 19 per cent in 1976-77. This trend was in strong contrast with the stabilisation or increase in private enterprise R & D which occurred over the years prior to 1976 in almost all other OECD countries.

Senator Jessop said that the Committee found that no clear national policy for science and technology existed in Australia and as a consequence there was little coherence, sense of purpose or direction in government support for IR & D. Senator Jessop said that it was vital that national policies for science and technology be developed as a matter of urgency to encourage IR & D in Australia.

I have expressed already my disappointment at the Government's failure to respond to that report and I hope that in the near future that report will be forthcoming. I hope also that the 61 major recommendations will be recognised by the Government as significant and as justifying further Government action in this important area.

I mentioned the importance of the computer and electronic industry not only to Australia but also to the world generally. I understand that if the computer industry has not already taken over from the motor industry as the world's largest industry, it soon will. The implications of this sort of technology to Australia, I believe, are quite significant. I understand that the Government has already taken the initiative to employ 15 scientists at the Waite Institute associated with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in Adelaide. They are to develop a super silicon chip. People might say that this advance of technological development could mean unemployment. I suggest that it does not mean unemployment at all but that it is necessary that the Government, in order to avoid unemployment, should recognise our future manpower needs in Australia as a result of the development of such an industry and should gear our education system so that we will be able to provide the personnel to fill the jobs which will open up as a result.

It was interesting to me, in reading about technological advances in the computer area in preparation for an address I was to give at the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science in Brisbane on the implications of technological change, to read a book called The Mighty Micro which was written by Dr Christopher Evans. He described the dramatic miniturisation that had occurred in the computer industry over a number of years. He used a very good example of an engineer required to construct a machine in 1945 that would perform the functions of the human brain. He said that such a machine would occupy the space of Greater London and would require a substantial power station to provide energy for that machine. He went on to say that when transistors become obvious in Australia in about the 1950s, that particular machine would be reduced to something of the size of the Albert Hall and would require a smaller generator to energise it. But the computer of the 1980s will assume about the same size as the human brain and will require a simple mercury cell to activate it. But the significant thing is this-Senator Baume will be able to correct me if I am wrong-I understand that the average human brain is capable of performing about a hundred functions per second. Whether my brain is capable of doing so or whether the brains of some of the members who sit opposite--

TALK.START.PARA: —All I know is that we are losing one million neurons a day, and I don't know what that does to our circuits.

—That is right. The amazing fact is that the computer of this decade will be able to perform one billion functions per second. To me, that is an incredible, mind-boggling figure. The implications of it open up wide possibilities for Australia. In order to capitalise on this we have to be able to research and develop these particular industrial initiatives in this country. The Bill suggests that we will be able to integrate our activities with those of other countries in this type of work that I am suggesting. It will be very important to Canberra where the Government is ngotiating to establish an electronics industry. The job opportunities that will flow from that will be quite immense. But we have to be alert to the need for further action in order to cope with this demand. I told honourable senators that our Committee, in its recommendations, made about 61 conclusions and recommendations, some of which apply to this Bill. On page 22 of the report, recommendation 56 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The principal instrument of the Federal government in encouraging IR&D is the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976.
Recommendation 57 reads:
The Acts intended to stimulate IR&D in Australia have so far failed in their purpose.
Recommendation 58 reads:

If the IR&D Incentives Act is to be a really effective instrument of government policy it must be related to national aims for industry and directed towards meeting priorities for strengthening industry.
Recommendation 59 states:
Low levels of IR&D incentive grants lead to a frittering away of public money without having any appreciable effect on the quality of the nation's technology.
Recommendation 60 states:
Government incentives for IR&D are nowhere near commensurate with the need, nor do they bear any other than incidental relation to national objectives.
We also went on to suggest that the Government should create and influence the climate for innovation. In paragraph 8.3, at page 234 we stated:

It is obvious that many government initiatives influence either directly or indirectly, business assessment of risk taking. The CSIRO in particular drew the attention of the Committee to the indirect effect on decision making of such factors as taxation policies, incentive schemes, employment policies, industry policies, cost structuring and raw material wage policies. As the 1977 White Paper on Manufacturing Industry pointed out, it is important to recognise that ''uncertainty about the continuation of major government initiatives from one government to the next can act as a significant barrier to the commitment of new capital''. Such changes in government policy may be necessary in political terms, but they often have unintended and lingering effects on industry and commerce.

We also made some reference to tariff protection. We suggested that in the past we paid a lot of money to protect inefficiency in industry. This money, in our view, would have been better spent to provide incentives for industries to innovate, develop and lift their production. Many other clauses in this document are meritorious and deserve favourable Government consideration. I look forward to the time in the near future when the Government will indicate to the Senate that it will take initiatives based on this document which was prepared after about 2 1/2 years of public inquiry. We saw more than 100 witnesses and we received many additional submissions from those whom we were able to examine personally.

All of these people-they came from universities, industries, the CSIRO and from similar areas-were experts in the field and pointed to the urgency to do something further to develop industry in Australia. I like to think that the Government will not ignore the value of a document such as this which has distilled the evidence from interested people throughout Australia on this very important subject. I support the Bill and look forward to further initiatives being taken as suggested by the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to honourable senators who have taken part in this second reading debate on the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill 1981. I refer first to the references by my colleague Senator Jessop to the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. I think it is fair to say that honourable senators place great value on the work of Senate committees to which they belong. They take the work of those committees very seriously and are very concerned about the way in which the recommendations are handled and the response which they eventually attract. As a former member of that Committee, though not for some time, I attest to the value of its work and I commend both its Chairman, Senator Jessop, and the members of the Committee for the report to which he referred in some detail. It was a most interesting document.

SPEECH.PARA: I inform the honourable senator that the Government is concerned that there has not been a response. It intends to make a formal response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee in the near future. I believe that the Senate would be interested to know that the majority of the Standing Committee's recommendations have already been accepted by the Government. I think that is something which should be placed on record in view of the concern expressed by the Chairman and his obvious interest in having his recommendations properly developed and implemented. I will not canvass the main provisions of the Bill. This has already been done by those who have spoken. However, it is necessary to address myself to the amendment which has been moved by Senator Button on behalf of the Opposition, and to several criticisms which were made.

The amendment has been circulated. I will go through it point by point and indicate the reasons why the Government will not accept the amendment and intends to vote against it. In relation to the assertion that there is a low level of Government investment in research and development compared with other technologically developed nations, we point out that public funding of research and development in Australia is higher than in almost any other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country. I have a figure of about 70 per cent in relation to Australian Government investment in research and development.

The second point asserts the failure of the Government to encourage significant private sector development. Again, the Government finds that proposition unacceptable. The Government has increased funding for industrial research and development from $14m in 1977-78 to $54m in 1980-81, which is really a most notable achievement in a time of financial stringency and indicates, probably in a way better than any other, the extent of the Government's commitment to this form of activity. Also, the grant limits which are available are increased by the Bill in two ways: They are increased to $750,000 per annum for project grants and to $40,000 per annum for commencement grants. In addition to that, the grant rate was increased from 25 per cent to 50 per cent in 1978-78 and later years.

The third assertion in the amendment states that there is a low level of Australian innovation, as measured by the number of patents taken out each year by Australian individuals and companies. Again, we feel that this can be answered. Australia performs about 1 per cent to 2 per cent of all the research and development effort undertaken by OECD countries. The majority of patents will, of course, be granted to residents of overseas countries, but it is worth noting that about 10 per cent of all the patents granted in this country are to locals, in spite of the fact that we perform about 1 per cent to 2 per cent of the research and development work within the OECD countries.

The fourth assertion is that there is a failure of the Government to stimulate Australian innovation in a number of areas which are specified in the amendment. The Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme is designed to foster and to encourage industrial research and development and innovation in these areas. Of course, a sizeable amount of the work and the budget of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is directed to these industries set out in the amendment.

The fifth point asserts that Australia is in a disadvantaged position in relation to technology transfer. A substantial amount of technology must be transferred to Australia if we are to develop a healthy technological base. The Government is taking appropriate steps to encourage the transfer of technology through the programs of the Department of Science and Technology. For example, the activities of the Technology Transfer Advisory Board are designed specifically to promote technological transfer, which is the basis of the amendment. I understand that the amendment seeks to condemn the Government for, as it states:
. . . losing national control over significant industries based on high levels of research and development, including . . .

The amendment then lists a number of industries. Australia does not have a large enough base to try to do everything. We are not out to try to reinvent the wheel. We are not out to start to develop all technology from the beginning. But Australian firms are now more competitive than they have been for many years. Australian industry has shown itself able to pursue overseas business opportunities on competitive terms. The assertion that there is any loss of competitiveness or any loss of the capacity of Australian industry to compete is simply not borne out by experience, including our experience in the industries operating in high technology areas. For example, my wife's brother runs a small electronic components manufacturing business and is able to make sales to the United States. Thus we are achieving manufacturing, selling and competing very effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —An example of that is provided by Telectronics, and its work on pacemakers, in Sydney.

—I agree with my colleague. That is an example of what is possible. The third assertion in the amendment is that the Senate rejects those parts of the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions brought down last week which eliminate or downgrade Commonwealth instrumentalities. However, that assertion is not related to the Bill before the Senate, which provides for the strengthening of the administrative arrangements for industrial research and development incentives rather than derogating them. It provides for an enlarged Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board, a technical standing committee for project grants and for a reconstituted incentives advisory committee to advise on public interest projects. I have taken time to proceed part by part through the proposed amendment to indicate why, in justice and in logic, it is one that we should not accept. I thank hounourable senators for their support of the Bill and commend it to the Senate.

The basic reason we want that wording deleted is simply that it seems selective in that it does not cover systematically, nor is the language general enough to do so, all the various kinds of bodies and interests that are the subject of exemption and exception elsewhere in the Bill. I suspect that the words have been put in there only through an abundance of caution. My concern is that their presence there creates a potential new set of interpretative hurdles which may stand in the way of a rational application of this Bill as a whole.

Sub-clause (2) is the subject of the second of these amendments. We think that a strong onus of proof is vested in the Government to satisfy the Parliament that there are good reasons for the exclusion of these bodies and persons operating where external territories are concerned. SPEECH.PARA: (6) Pages 5 and 6, clause 5, lines 20 to 40 (page 5) and 1 to 7 (page 6) leave out the clause insert the following clauses:

5. For the purposes of this Act-

The object of the amendment is to treat this clause, which deals with courts, judicial offices, certain industrial tribunals and their registries, in such a way that those bodies are not exempt from the operation of the Act so far as their administrative procedures, properly so-called, are concerned. This was the subject of discussion and commentary in the Senate Committee report in paragraphs 12.29 to 12.30 and paragraphs 12.33 to 12.34. In those paragraphs the point was made that whilst there are obviously good reasons for excluding the operation of this kind of legislation where it might intrude on the independence of the judiciary and whilst it certainly should not operate as an alternative means for litigants to obtain discovery of court documents in the course of their litigation, there was a clearly definable area of court and tribunal activity which was legiti- mately the subject of public interest so far as efficient administration was concerned. The Bill ought to be amended to make this clear.

The kind of matters that the Committee had in mind as justifying the operation of the Bill were questions relating to the number of sitting days, the number of cases determined, the number of cases withdrawn, the number of cases which were subsequently appealed, criminal cases in which bail was awarded and so on. The utility, or indeed the necessity, for an exemption for administrative questions of this kind is in fact made more obvious by the recent change in the legislation governing the High Court of Australia. These sorts of administrative questions are now clearly within the Court's jurisdiction, whereas previously the majority of administrative matters of this kind were performed by or through the Attorney-General's Department and as such were the subject of ordinary access procedures so far as information was concerned.

If questions of administrative efficiency of this kind are now to be locked away within the bosom of the institution, as a result of legislative changes of the kind that have recently been made concerning the High Court, it becomes that much more important for there to be access procedures available to people to ensure that information of the kind to which I am referring can be extracted. That is the justification for the amendment. The Senate committee does not see this as interfering or trespassing in any way with the independence of these bodies which, as a part of our constitutional system, it is important to preserve. It is a distinction which is familiar and understood and the language in which the amendment is cast is sufficiently clear and precise, in our view, to be accommodated directly by the Government. I hope that is exactly what happens.

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 6, clause 6, sub-clause (5), lines 22 to 29, leave out the sub-clause, insert the following sub-clauses:
'(5) The regulations may amend Schedule 1-
(a) by inserting an additional provision or additional provisions in Part I of Schedule 1, being a provision or provisions relating to a body;
(b) by deleting from Part I of Schedule 1 any body specified in Part I of that Schedule;

(c) by inserting an additional provision or additional provisions in Part II of Schedule 1, being a provision relating to a particular category or particular categories of documents in relation to a body or bodies;
(d) by deleting from Part II of Schedule 1 any item listed in Part I of that Schedule; or
(e) by amending in Part II of Schedule 1 any item listed in Part II of the Schedule.
'(6) A regulation made for the purposes of sub-section (5) shall not take effect until each House of the Parliament has resolved that it take effect.
'(7) Sub-sections 48(4), (5), (5A) and (6) and Section 49 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 do not apply to regulations made in accordance with this section.'

This amendment relates to this clause which deals with exemption of certain bodies. It is the provision whereby the Government exempts certain bodies from the operation of the Act. This is an important clause and this amendment is one of some significance. I wish to draw attention to the fact that in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitution and Legal Affairs recommendation No. 33 is in the following terms:

The exemption of any agencies or classes of documents of an agency and the determination of whether a body is part of a specified agency should be achieved by listing them in a schedule to the Freedom of Information Bill with subsequent amendment to that schedule occurring by means of regulation taking effect only upon affirmative resolution of both Houses.
The Government has accepted, in part, the recommendations which the Senate Committee made. I should read the response from the Government. It stated:

The Government accepts the recommendation that initial exemptions from the Act should be made in a schedule to the Act. Whilst the Government is of the view that deletions of bodies included in the original schedule should be by amendment to the Act, subsequent additions to the schedule might be made by regulation, which would be subject to the normal disallowance procedures.

So the Government accepts the fact-and I congratulate the Government on doing this-that in the Act are the bodies which the Government proposes to exempt and which senators will find now in Parts I and II of the Schedule to the Act. That will be, of course, a matter for debate by this Committee at a later stage.

The powers under which this is done do not allow for the proposal which the Senate Committee put. It said that if we increase the number of bodies that are to be excluded entirely from the operations of the Freedom of Information Act or from Part II of the Schedule-in particular many of those bodies will have documents which relate to competitive, commercial operations-the alterations in respect of those documents and the perhaps vast widening of the ambit of exclusion from the Act or the reduction in the other way as well will be achieved by regulation and will not be debated necessarily in this Parliament at all. In effect, this is one of the hidden exemptions in the Bill and it could be a very considerable exemption.

I say that there may be no parliamentary scrutiny because it is very doubtful whether the normal parliamentary scrutiny with which the Committee is very familiar-including the referral of all regulations to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and on occasions consideration of disallowance on the recommendation of that Committee or on the recommendation of any senator, will happen. If, in fact, the Government in future proposes to add to the Schedule, it can do so by regulation.

The Regulations and Ordinances Committee, of course, is subject to and works upon four criteria only. Perhaps the most likely criterion that it could use-and probably the only one-is that it interferes with the rights and liberties of the citizen. In a sense it may be said that to remove some organisation from scrutiny of freedom of information interferes with rights and liberties. It is perhaps tenuous at the best. In fact, it is unlikely that that Committee would be in a position to scrutinise carefully that sort of organisation or that sort of decision by the Government. Then, of course, it would have to bring before this chamber a discussion and a debate on that exclusion.

Consequently, the recommendation of the Senate Committee was that the method of making alterations to exemptions should be my means of an affirmative resolution. It should be done by some action which requires debate in both chambers. This is an important recommendation. Because it is a matter of proceeding to change the ambit of the Freedom of Information Act, this recommendation was made. Provision also is made that such a change in the Act should not take effect until it is, in fact, affirmed by both Houses of Parliament. In other words, we should not find the situation where a regulation is made excluding some organisation from any action under the Act, which might be done for some purpose by some government, and where some months later there is a discussion, at the best for possible disallowance of that regulation. The fact is that I think such regulations should not take effect until affirmed.

In the course of the Senate Committee's consideration of this Bill, in two other areas it recommended the same use of affirmative resolution which has been used on a number of occasions in this Parliament. I shall give as examples section 26 (3) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act and section 24 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Senators will be familiar with that area where we have to pass affirmative resolutions regarding the redistribution proposals to the States because we regard those matters as important and requiring scrutiny by the Parliament.

As I have said, we have recommended in two other areas in this Senate report the use of the affirmative resolution. One area is chapter 8.43 in which we deal with the reduction of times. This refers to recommendation 14 of the Senate Comittee. We made recommendations whereby the times for compliance with the provisions of the Act could be reduced from 60 days-it is proposed at the moment to reduce it to 45 days-and later to 30 days. These important changes ought to be done by affirmative resolution. The other area is in chapter 21.13 for which another Schedule was proposed by the Committee for prescribed secrecy provisions. If that is put into the Act, further prescribed secrecy provisions or changes that may be made to that Schedule would, under our recommendation 58 (b), be done by the same affirmative resolution proposal.

Honourable senators will see from the terms of the amendment which is before them that one provision, sub-section (7), makes provision that the various sub-sections of the Acts Intepretation Act do not apply to regulations made in accordance with this section. Those are provisions relating to disallowance which would not be applicable if, in fact, the proposed changes to the Schedule would have to come before the Senate in any event to be affirmatively upheld. For these reasons, I propose that this amendment be inserted in clause 6 so that we can be sure that Parliament has a real and constant obligation to know what further changes are to be proposed, whether organisations are to be made subject to the Act or whether their present exclusion is to be taken away, and whether new organisations for some good reason were to be given that privilege, not to be answerable to the people and not to provide materials and documents as the Act provides. Because of the importance which the Schedule involves and because of the recommendations that the Senate Committee put before this chamber, I recommend this amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not, of course, debating the actual bodies listed in the Parts of the Schedule. Probably that will be the subject of fairly lengthy consideration at a later date. —It is years old.
—Perhaps Senator Hamer will tell me when it has been used and how effective it has proved to be, and so on.
—Try the Commonwealth Electoral Act since 1918.
—Has it been used?
—Yes. It is used every time there is a new distribution. It seems to work pretty well for the Liberals.

—We are talking about regulations, not about approving a redistribution. The position with the regulation is that it could be made very quickly by government. SPEECH.PARA: Why on earth one wants to make a great song and dance and issue about a matter of this kind I just do not know. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I want to make clear my own position about security agencies as far as the Schedule is concerned. I would not support any attempt to remove the security and intelligence agencies from the Schedule as it currently stands in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that there are a couple of points to make. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to support what Senator Puplick has said. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I agree that this is not a very serious or basic matter. The amendment provides for a simpler mechanism instead of a more complicated one. That seems to be its merit. SPEECH.PARA: I believe, and the Australian Democrats believe, that anything that affects the national security should be exempt. There should be absolutely no question about that matter, and we raise no question about it. That has happened because they were exempt from any kind of criticism, any kind of check from the Parliament or any other authority in the land. I suggest that they have attracted unsavoury elements-people who act above and beyond the law. Time and again we have seen examples from all over the world of financial discrepancies and illegalities which I do not believe a healthy society should have. I repeat that national security aspects should be absolutely exempt. I do not think that it is difficult to see that this happens. Very clear definitions could be laid down in the third schedule.

The Australian Democrats will lean over backwards to see that they protect security organisations as far as possible. I say that in the interests of the security organisations. I would have thought that a security organisation to which these kinds of safeguards are available would be a stronger and better one and that the people running it would have more strength to hand to deal with people of unsavoury attitudes who-it could be purely accidental-have been brought into the organisation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps because of my background I am determined that security and intelligence organisations should remain exempt from freedom of information legislation. SPEECH.PARA: When the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs put forward this device of a regulation, followed by an affirmative resolution of both houses of parliament, we were trying to streamline procedures. What we felt was most important was that both additions and deletions should be considered by both houses of parliament. They should not be slipped through by regulation which was considered only by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which had different terms of reference and was generally an unsuitable body. We wanted both Houses of Parliament to direct their attention to any additions and deletions from this list of exempt bodies. I can accept the Attorney's point of view that perhaps, if he wishes and is prepared to accept the encroachment into parliamentary time, this could be done only by an Act of Parliament. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We seem to have forgotten that the point we are debating is not the merit or otherwise of the exemption of the security agencies from the Schedule but rather simply the procedure by which agencies of all kinds are put on and taken off the Schedule. However, I am nothing if not a realist in these matters and it is obvious that attitudes to the exemption of security agencies are going to determine the way this chamber votes on this clause-whether or not, technically speaking, that is relevant. Accordingly, I think the way through this has been most neatly devised probably by what Senator Missen suggested, that is, that security agencies be treated separately either by way of a separate Schedule or a separate provision in the legislation and that their insertion in the legislation and their possible future removal from it be governed by the normal procedures which apply to amendments to an Act of Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As irrational as I think the distinction is in this respect, it appears to be the kind of thing that would at least satisfy in the first instance the concern of those who are having difficulties about security agencies possibly being subject to more flexible procedures than other organisations. So for the sake of a quite life I would support the postponement of this clause to enable some provision to be drafted along those lines to make security agencies distinct from other classes of agencies.

I do, however, maintain my strong support for the notion that agencies generally ought to be able to be both inserted in and excluded from the Schedule by way of an affirmative action procedure. Nothing I have heard from any speaker tonight dissuades me from that point of view. I think it is important to have a more technically flexible procedure to get organisations on and off the Schedule as occasions demand, simply because of the procedural reality that if something is embodied in an Act of Parliament and can be amended only by an Act of Parliament it is very largely for practical purposes, given the way government works, frozen. Legislative changes are subject to a whole series of procedures-departmental, Cabinet and otherwise-to which other forms of parliamentary procedures are not. I see it a welcome degree of flexibility so far as agencies generally are concerned if they could be put on and taken off the Schedule by means of this affirmative resolution procedure.

In doing so, I am utterly unable to see how the system is put at risk. I am utterly unable to see how the Parliament in a fit of absent-mindedness, as it were, could accede to the removal or, for that matter, the insertion of an agency without really knowing what it was doing or appreciating the significance of its action. The only point that the Attorney seemed able to produce to justify his assertion that there is a dangerous degree of flexibility in this procedure was the motion that an affirmative resolution could be introduced sumultaneously into both Houses and that we would lose the consequential steps that are involved in legislation moving from one House to another which is the way our legislative process presently works. But does not the Attorney remember that all that really matters in the sequential process operating effectively simultaneously is whether one party has a majority in both Houses and, indeed, the disposition of both Houses to pass something quickly?

Has he forgotten all about the common informers legislation which was passed in response to the Webster case, I think in 1975? The Bill was introduced-I think it was drafted that afternoon-into the House of Representatives and it was out of the Senate literally within, I think, 53 minutes. That was the time it took for its progress from one House to the other. I might add that the superannuation Bill for parliamentarianss went through both Houses almost as quickly. So the notion of public interest being put at risk by the absence of the sequential move through both Houses is, with respect, palpable nonsense. What matters is that there be the requirement of affirmation by both Houses. I particularly do not like that in principle for other sorts of reasons but I am cheerfully willing to accede to it in this context andI think it is an ample safeguard.

The only other string the Attorney seems to have to his bow when we move beyond the defence area is that any such procedure is, as he put it, new fangled. It is not entirely newfangled because it has been used in other contexts and some of them have already been mentioned in debate. I suggest to adopt that view as a sort of conclusive knock-out blow in argument is to adopt Professor Cornford's notorious principle of the dangerous precedent which has as one of its corollaries the proposition that nothing should ever be done for the first time. I think it would be very dangerous if we were to adopt our approach to legislation and the desirability of legislation by reference to any such principle.

In summary, I support the postponement of this clause so that it can be amended in the way suggested by Senator Missen which is a separate treatment, irrational as I think that might be, for security agencies to be incorporated in the legislation in the first instance and only able to be taken out by legislative amendment but with the Committee proposed treatment of affirmative resolution being the mode of treatment applicable to all other forms of agencies. Clause 7. Publication of information concerning functions and documents of agencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Pages 6 and 7, clause 7 sub-clause (1) lines 37 to 40 (p. 6) 1 to 6 (p. 7) leave out sub-paragraphs (i) and (ii), insert the following sub-paragraphs:

'(i) a statement setting out particulars of the organisation and functions of the agency, indicating, as far as practicable, the decision-making powers and other powers affecting members of the public that are involved in those functions;

'(ii) a statement setting out particulars or any arrangements that exist for bodies or persons outside the Commonwealth administration to participate, either through consultative procedures, the making of representations or otherwise, and whether by direct or indirect means, in the formulation of policy by the agency, or in the administration by the agency, of any enactment or scheme;

'(iiA) a statement of the categories of documents that are maintained in the possession of the agency, being a statement that sets out, as separate categories of documents, categories of such documents, if any, as are referred to in paragraph 11(1)(b) or (c) and categories of documents, if any, not being documents so referred to, as are customarily made available to the public, otherwise than under this Act, free of charge upon request;
'(iiB) a statement of particulars of the facilities, if any, provided by the agency for enabling members of the public to obtain physical access to the documents of the agency; and'.

I do not think that this amendment will cause as much concern to the Committee as some of the amendments to previous clauses and, no doubt, to many subsequent ones. What we are dealing with here is the establishment of practices whereby the rights which are conferred by this Bill, or the Act when it has passed through this Parliament, will operate in a context whereby official co-operation and assistance will ensure that those rights really will become real, concrete and effective. So, what clause 7 is about is trying to create a scheme whereby the public is given at the outset and without any reference to any request for a particular document, such information as will help the public to determine most conveniently and expeditiously what documents may be available and to take steps to contact the official within the organisation concerned to get hold of those particular documents.

What is envisaged is that the Commonwealth Government Directory will become the main vehicle whereby there shall be published by an agency statements concerning the organisation and functions of that agency, together with the various decision-making powers that are relevant to its operation and other powers which may affect members of the public. What we have attempted to do by this amendment is merely in conformity with the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal affairs. We have attempted to add some matters whereby the statements in the Commonwealth Government Directory might be expanded to enable a member of the public to identify more easily and to get hold of the documents to which that member of the public wants access. In particular, for example, we say that there should be within the Government Directory a note of those documents which are open to public access as a result of the operation of some other enactment, that is, some enactment other than the Freedom of Information Bill. We refer in particular to paragraph 11 (1) (b):
A document that is open to public access, as part of a public register or otherwise, in accordance with another enactment, where that access is subject to a fee or other charge.

We also say that the Government Directory should also list those documents that are available for purchase by the public in accordance with such arrangements as may be made by the agency. In other words, there should be listed not only those documents which may become available under the freedom of information legislation but also other documents to which the public ought to have access. We also add that there should be some indication of what physical arrangements might be made to enable a member of the public to obtain access. To take an obvious example, it might be indicated in the Directory that there are reading rooms available in certain situations where agencies could make the Directory and other documents available.

The Government and Senator Durack are to be commended on the additional clause 7 (1) (a) (iii) whereby in this new 1981 Freedom of Information Bill it is provided that there shall be published as soon as practicable:

a statement of any information that needs to be available to the public concerning particular procedures of the agency in relation to Part III, and particulars of the officer or officers to whom, and the place or places at which, initial inquiries concerning access to documents may be directed;
I recall that the Senate Committee was particularly concerned that some such paragraph should appear in the Bill and we are indeed gratified that it does so appear.

I do not think I need take up the time of the Committee by saying much more on this matter. As I say, it is very important that the public, before a particular request is made, has access to as much information as possible about how to approach the agency, about to whom to make the initial approach and to have some understanding of the documents within the agency's care or disposal. That is what our amendment seeks to do. It is entirely in conformity with the findings of the Senate Standing Committee. For that reason, I commend the amendment to the Committee.
