Clause 8. Certain documents to be available for inspection and purchase.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 7, clause 8, sub1clause (1), paragraph (a), line 40. insert after ''precedents'', including, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, precedents in the nature of letters of advice providing information to bodies or persons outside the Commonwealth administration; or''

We are dealing with documents which an individual citizen will have access to and which will help him to understand the way in which the Commonwealth interprets the Acts, the regulations and the ordinances for which it is responsible for administering. Clearly, it is indicated in the existing clause 8 (1) that this is to include manuals or other documents containing interpretations, rules, guidelines, practices or precedents. It goes in to refer to documents containing particulars of such a scheme, not being particulars contained in an enactment as published apart from this legislation. This simply seeks to say that, where there have been statements made by the Commonwealth or by an agency of the Commonwealth which indicate the way in which the Commonwealth or the agency interprets the Act or regulation which is in question and that statement of how the Commonwealth or the agency interprets the matter in question was set by the Commonwealth or the agency to somebody outside the Commonwealth's administration, that should also be included in the material which is made available for public inspection and purchase. I hasten to add that I would not expect that this would be done in a way which would reveal the name of the person or persons outside the Commonwealth's administration to whom this explanation was made.

I think it would be perfectly easy to provide that the interpretation which has been given could be given in a way which does not say, for instance, that this was the interpretation which was addressed to me when I asked for an explanation of the interpretation, or was addressed to some body of lawyers or to anybody who made the request. I think it is simply saying that it ought to be possible to provide, within the overall administration, accessibility for members of the public to a document which purports to say: 'This is how the Commonwealth or the agency interprets this piece of legislation. This was advice given not within the bureaucracy by way of a printed manual, an instruction to officers or a directive from a Minister about an interpretation, but an interpretation which was made available to somebody outside and which is the precedent which is being followed'.

I believe that one can do that while protecting the confidentiality and the ananymity of the person to whom that advice was sent. That certainly is not part of the relative interest which any individual would have in ascertaining this advice. Otherwise it is not seeking to make a major addition to the document, because the document already states that practices or precedents should be made available. This simply refers to statements of precedent which are in the nature of letters or advice providing information-that is all it says-to persons or bodies outside the Commonwealth's administration. I would not see this as imposing a great burden, nor would I see it as a departure from any substantial practice in which the Government has previously engaged. It is the provision of information which, on previous occasions, has already gone to somebody outside the Commonwealth's administration which is now being sought by an individual or group also outside the Commonwealth's administration to allow him or them to get a clearer understanding of the intention and the interpretation of the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite happy to accede to this amendment. I think it spells out in further detail what is implicit in the working of the Bill. I have no problem with it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Page 7, clause 8, sub-clause (1), after paragraph (b) insert the following paragraphs:
''(c) documents containing statements of the matter, or intended manner, of administration or enforcement of such an enactment or scheme; or

(d) documents containing statements of the procedures to be followed in detecting or investigating breaches or evasions or possible breaches or evasions of such an enactment or of the law relating to such a scheme.''

Here again is the same sort of point. It seeks to spell out in some detail matters which may well have been implicit in what the current clause says. It is a question of an individual-perhaps I ought to avoid the use of the term 'citizen' because it does not apply just to a citizen; it applies to non-citizens-who goes to a Commonwealth department seeking information. He will be enabled to get hold of copies of manuals or documents we have previously been referring to in relation to the amendment I moved and which the Attorney-General accepted, and documents containing particulars of such a scheme, which is the existing clause 8 (1) (b). This goes on to say that if there are-there may well not be-documents which give a guide to the way in which the scheme or legislation is to be administered or to be enforced or there are documents which contain statements about procedures-I stress the word 'procedures'-to be followed in detecting breaches or possible breaches or evasions or possible evasions of the legislation in question, they should also be available to the inquiring individual.

I appreciate as far as breaches or evasions are concerned that procedures do not have to be in very great detail. They may well simply state the sort of things that have to be established in order to demonstrate or to prove that there has been a breach or evasion or a possible breach or evasion of an enactment of the law relating to such a scheme. This again goes to the process of spelling out in detail what material will be available for public inspection or purchase under the general heading of clause 8 (1). I commend it to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no problem with the addition of paragraph (c), which is in the same category as the earlier amendment which I agreed to of spelling out the detail, but I have real difficulties about the suggested paragraph (d), which refers to documents containing statements of the procedures to be followed in detecting or investigating breaches or evasions or possible breaches or evasions of such an enactment. It appears to me to be giving fairly clear signals to people who may be intending to try to evade. Having found out the intended manner of the administration, we tell them how we are going to detect or investigate breaches or evasions. I should have thought that that would give them signals as to how they might more successfully practice such evasion. There is a general exemption of documents in the law enforcement area, and this sort of document may fall within that category. If so the provision would become pointless. If it does not fall within that exemption-I have not given close thought to whether it may fall within some other area-it just seems to offer an unnecessary risk. Why we would want to give statements to people about how we intended to detect or investigate breaches or evasions I cannot imagine. Therefore, although the Government can accept proposed new paragraph (c) of sub-clause (1) it cannot accept proposed new paragraph (d).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to the Attorney-General's concern is that new paragraph (d) is to be read in conjunction with clause 32, which provides for an exemption in relation to law enforcement and public safety documents. A substantial measure of that exemption is to be retained, even under the amendments to it which have been circulated. Proposed new paragraph (d) is cast as broadly as it is because it is clearly desired to bring within the scope of prima facie availability police standing orders and police manuals of the kind which traditionally have governed such things as the police use of firearms, arrest procedures, and search and surveillance and interrogation procedures-the kinds of things which have always been part of the armoury of the courts in most jurisdictions of Australia, in determining the traditional operation of the judges' rules, the admissibility of evidence, the exercise of the court's discretion in regard to admissibility and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not talking here about an unfamiliar body of material. It is merely the ordinary material which basically governs the exercise of police investigative and arrest powers. A very strong argument has been articulated, especially by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its criminal investigation report of 1975, for making this material available-as indeed it is in many jurisdictions. I am not sure of the precise position in the Australian Capital Territory insofar as the Australian Federal Police are concerned. There has been an extraordinary sensitivity on the part of some police forces in regard to making this sort of material available.

I repeat the amendment is moved against the background of clause 32, which is sufficiently precise, and will remain so, to exempt material which embodies procedures of a sophisticated kind that one would not wish to fall into the hands of potential law breakers. I refer to complicated evasion detection techniques of the kind that are operated by the Taxation Office and the more involved techniques used by the fraud squads of our police forces. These, quite reasonably, might be regarded as properly exempt. They would be covered by the language of clause 32. Therefore, I do not believe that the Attorney-General need worry about the effect of proposed new paragraph (d), provided clause 32 remains in a reasonable rigorous form. I ask him to accept the amendment on that basis. It brings clearly within the scope of the basic Bill a great deal of police manual type material which ought to be available to the public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pursue the point just made by Senator Evans and I would be grateful if the Attorney-General would explain his difficulty with the proposed amendment. I can understand them if it were not read in conjunction with clause 32. That clause, which as I understand it, is not to be substantially amended, provides:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) A document is an exempt document if its disclosure under this Act would, or could reasonably be expected to-
(a) prejudice the conduct of an investigation of an offence, or possible offence, against the law . . .
That clause would seem to me to meet the difficulty which the Attorney-General has with the proposed amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept for one minute the soothing propositions presented by Senator Evans. If one examines clause 32 one finds that it deals with documents which prejudice the conduct of an investigation of an offence, or possible offence, against the law; or disclose the existence of a source of information in relation to the enforcement of law-presumably when an offence has been committed. Those provisions deal with documents which concern the investigation of an offence that has occurred. The breadth of proposed new paragraph (d) is such as to embrace cases involving not just the police area but, more importantly, the tax and social security area, especially the former. One would be required to show the procedures to be followed in detecting or investigating breaches or evasions, or possible breaches or evasions. In other words, one would have to signal to potential tax evaders the methods and procedures that were to be adopted in detecting them. We have heard a lot from Senator Evans about tax evasion, although I might say that this Government has taken more action in that regard than has any Labor government. The proposed amendment would take us into a very dangerous field; I do not know where we might end up. My fear as to where we might be going with this sounds all sorts of warning signals in my mind and makes me take the stand that I do.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that Senator Evans' example about documents concerning criminal investigation procedures has anything to do with the proposed provision. His example concerned the exercise of police powers of arrest, interrogation and so on. The proposed provision is much wider than that. It signals the contents of what I would think should be very confidential documents in regard to taxation and social security in particular, and doubtless police activities as well. In short, I believe that that way useful information could be provided to criminals and potential criminals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, may I suggest that if this impasse with regard to proposed new paragraph (d) persists, paragraphs (c) and paragraph (d) should be the subject of separate questions. Secondly, I would like to test the Attorney's objections to proposed new paragraph (d) against the test of clause 32 (2) (a) and 32 (2) (c). Clause 32 (2) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: A document is an exempt document if its disclosure under this Act, would, or could reasonably be expected to-
(a) prejudice the carrying on generally of investigations concerning breaches or evasions of the law;
More significantly, clause 32 (c) provides:
A document is an exempt document if its disclosure under this Act, would, or could reasonably be expected to-

disclose lawful methods or procedures for preventing, detecting, investigating, or dealing with matters arising out of, breaches or evasions of the law the disclosure of which, would, or would be reasonably likely to, prejudice the effectiveness of those methods or procedures;

Clause 32(2) (c) is not to be the subject of any proposed amendment during this debate. Therefore, we have clearly an overriding exemption which is not the subject of dispute between the Committee and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) or indeed at this stage between anybody and the Attorney-General and which in effect, I believe, takes care of those matters that the Attorney-General is concerned about, which concern I share. It takes care of those matters which could, be presented in a manual or in a way which would enable a potential law breaker or a potential tax evader to say: 'These are the procedures to be used by the agency which relate specifically to how it would detect a breach or evasion of the law or a possible breach or evasion of the law'.

The wording of clause 32(2) (c) seems to me to be fairly precise-that a document is exempt if it discloses lawful methods or procedures the aim of which is preventing, detecting or investigating breaches or evasions of the law or deals with matters arising out of breaches or evasions of the law where the disclosure of that information would or, even further, would be reasonably likely to prejudice the effectiveness of those methods or procedures. I am interested as to whether the Attorney-General believes that proposed new paragraph (d) would in fact not be regarded as totally subservient to the specific exemption provisions of clause 32(2) (c) which I believe takes up the concerns that the Attorney-General has about the prior disclosure of methods for investigating breaches or evasions of the law or possible breaches or evasions of the law which-I share his concern-one would not want to make public in advance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) may well have a reasonable argument in this case because the actual wording, which I think should be tightened up, is 'documents containing statements of the procedures to be followed'. I would have thought even the words 'documents concerning descriptions of the procedure's or 'describing the procedures to be followed' would be much closer to what Senator Evans urged in his explanation. I think the Attorney-General has a point here. The words 'statements of procedures to be followed' could be read as a specific in a particular case, whereas the words 'documents describing procedures to be followed' indicate not a particular but a generality. I think that is really what Senator Evans was looking for. It is my suggestion that we should ask the Attorney-General whether he would consider some reframing of this proposed amendment which would come closer to his view. I do not really think it is right that it should be passed exactly as it stands now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support what Senator Puplick has said now about the operation of clause 32 (2) (c), which is obviously squarely designed to accommodate that preventative focus of material of this kind which seems to be the primary concern of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). I hope that he will be prepared to reconsider his position in the light of having that drawn to his attention. But should he still be minded to be a bit nervous about this proposed new paragraph in its present form, he might also be prepared to consider not so much the linguistic change which I think Senator Mason was hinting at, but an acceptance of proposed new paragraph (d) with the deletion of the words 'detecting or' in line two so that it will simply read:

SPEECH.PARA: Documents containing statements of the procedures to be followed in investigating breaches or evasions-

I think on reflection the expression 'detecting' does have a wider reach than is strictly necessary to focus on the sorts of documents which I, for one, want to see disclosed as a basic rule under this clause, namely, police manuals and standing orders of the Victorian Brown Bomber kind-that notoriously secret volume-and its federal equivalents. They are the sorts of things at which I think this is clearly directed. I would be happy if that investigative focus was retained in proposed new paragraph (d) rather than the possible wider language which is there at the moment. I repeat: This is really an unnecessary accommodation of the Attorney-General's nervousness because it would appear that clause 32 (2) (c), which nobody wants to amend, would operate as a perfect safeguard against the dangers that he foresees.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not prepared to consider any further tinkering around with this clause to make some verbal changes in it or otherwise. I hope I have made my position on it clear. I am not impressed by suggestions that it is covered by clause 32 (2) (c) because, if it is, it is a quite pointless provision to put in the Bill. This amendment proposes an addition to the Bill, the purpose of which is by no means clear to me and which contains inherent dangers. If those dangers are eliminated by clause 32 (2) (c), why put it in at all? In other words, we would have exactly the same situation. The proposed amendment seems to be either pointless or to have dangers in it. I do not see what possible merit there is in including it and in wasting the time of the Committee and of my officers in trying to make changes to it. I am afraid that I just cannot see what point there is in persisting with an investigation of this proposed amendment.

—I would like to clarify the form in which the proposed amendment has been put to the chamber. There have been suggestions that the words 'detecting or' should be deleted from the proposed new paragraph (d). Their deletion would make some difference to my attitude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the Senate to remove the words 'detecting or' from paragraph (d) of the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I further ask Senator Puplick, because it is an important part of Senator Evans's comprehension, whether he will not also consider a proposed amendment which simply contains the words 'documents describing procedures' because I think my point about general and specific cases is a valid one. If the proposed new paragraph were to contain the words 'documents containing statements of the procedures to be followed', it could refer to an individual case. But if it contained the words 'documents describing the procedures to be followed in investigating', it would obviously refer to the sorts of documents-police manuals or handbooks-that Senator Evans mentioned. I really think that would strengthen the proposed amendment and I ask Senator Puplick's opinion of that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I prevail again on the patience of endurance of the Committee to accommodate Senator Mason's proposed amendment to my proposed amendment by seeking leave to move proposed new paragraph (d) in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Documents describing the procedures to be followed in investigating breaches or evasions or possible breaches or evasions of such an enactment or of the law relating to such a scheme.
Leave granted.

I think it would be acceptable to everybody if the questions with regard to proposed new paragraphs (c) and (d) were put separately because paragraph (c) is not disputed by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack).

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Committee that the questions with regard to proposed new paragraphs (c) and (d) be put separately? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed new paragraph (d) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Documents describing the procedures to be followed in investigating breaches or evasions or possible breaches or evasions of such an enactment or of the law relating to such a scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like Senator Puplick to explain to me the difference between documents containing statements of procedures and documents decribing the procedures. I can understand the difference is perhaps between detecting and investigating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was seeking to accommodate Senator Mason's suggestion. The point was made that a document which contains a statement of the procedures may well, in fact, be a document dealing with particularities of a procedure. In other words, it may deal with the way in which an investigation in proceeding whereas describing the procedures describes not any particularities but rather a generality of procedure to be followed in terms of dealing with cases that fall within one class or description. I was seeking to accommodate what Senator Evans raised on the question of detecting or investigating. I understand that to relate to much to the same point, that is, that the actual process of detecting may relate very specifically to a case.

SPEECH.PARA: Alternatively, there can be a difference between the processes of detecting breaches or evasions of the law or such a scheme whereas the procedures in investigating the breaches or evasions or possible breaches or evasions goes to the point that Senator Evans raised at an earlier stage about precisely what sort of documents we are seeking to have exposed under sub-clause (d). They are essentially statements about common rules and procedures which people involved in investigating breaches or possible breaches or evasions of enactments are normally constrained by or normally operate under.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are one or two further points to be explained if the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is concerned by the meaning. The meaning could even go further, I suggest, to include documents describing the general procedures. This again gets away from the specific point. But the Attorney does not see the difference between the amended version and the original wording. I think that would merely strengthen that point.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That proposed new paragraph (d), (Senator Puplick's amendment) be agreed to as amended.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Page 8, clause 8, sub-clause (2), paragraph (c), lines 10 to 13, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph,

'(c) not later than 3 months after the publication of the statement under paragraph (b) and thereafter at intervals of not more than 3 months, cause to be published in the Gazette statements bringing up to date the information contained in the previous statement or statements.'
The current provision, which the amendment seeks to leave out, reads:

. . . during the year commencing on 1 January next following the publication of the statement under paragraph (b) and . . . during each succeeding year, cause to be published in the Gazette statements bringing up to date the information contained in the previous statement or statements.

In other words, the amendment seeks to change from 12 months to three months the period after which the documents referred to in the preceding paragraph must be updated. The preceding paragraph provides that the principal officer of an agency shall:

not later than 12 months after the commencement of this Part, cause to be published in the Gazette a statement (which may take the form of an index) specifying the documents of which copies are, at the time of preparation of the statement, so available and the place or places where copies may be inspected and may be purchased . . .

In other words, an agency no later than 12 months after the Act comes into operation, shall cause to be published in the Gazette a statement about the documents which that agency holds and which are available for inspection. The Bill as it stands states essentially that there ought to be an update on that basis every 12 months. The proposed amendment states that instead an update ought to be published in the Gazette every three months simply saying what has happened in the course of the three months to the published index as it appeared originally under the terms of clause 8(2)(b). That will allow people a more contemporaneous access to information and a greater ability to keep themselves informed of changes which agencies are making in the preparation and presentation of documents for public inspection. I commend the clause to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not prepared to accede to the amendment moved by Senator Puplick, because of its resource implications. The fact of the matter is that a tremendous amount of information is to be provided in accordance with the provisions of clauses 7 and 8 of the Bill. I have agreed to amendments which spell out, and which in fact may add to, the information that is produced. As I have said, I think they are in the spirit of clauses 7 and 8, but they do require a great deal of information to be provided about the operations of agencies. They will impose very considerable obligations on agencies, departments and authorities. A great deal of work will be required to bring them into operation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said on many occasions both in this chamber and outside it, that the Government is particularly concerned, especially at this time, with the additional resources that may be required to meet the obligations it will have under this legislation. The obligations have been proposed at a time when the Public Service has assumed many additional obligations in the shape of administrative appeals, Ombudsman's procedures and so on. Therefore I think a reasonable balance has to be struck. In the light of Government policy the resources of the Public Service will not be expanded, and in fact will be reduced overall. A greater burden will thereby be imposed on it in trying to satisfy its obligations under this legislation.

The legislation provides for the publication of documents in the nature of manuals and so forth which set out a great deal of information. It provides that during each succeeding year commencing on 1 January following the publication of a statement in the Government Gazette, information will be provided in the Gazette bringing that statement up to date. The amendment seeks to go further to require that the statement be updated at intervals of not more than three months. Four times the amount of work provided in the Bill is required by the amendment. It requires the updating to be done four times every year instead of once every year. I think that is taking the matter too far. To expect agencies to do that is to place too great an obligation upon them. For that reason, and for that reason alone, the Government is not prepared to accept this amendment.

I might say that there are other amendments in the same category. The Government has given a great deal of attention to the whole question of the strain on resources which will be presented by this legislation. I regret to say that the Government has considered and is not prepared to accept at this stage any amendments which appear significantly to add to those resource implications. In the future, when we have had the opportunity of seeing what sorts of demands are made and what sorts of resources have to be assigned to administering this legislation, we may be prepared to consider these matters. But at this stage we are completely in the dark as to what will be the demands on the Public Service, with the very limited resources it will have to deal with these obligations. We believe that the only sensible course is to hasten slowly and to obtain experience in how the legislation works and what the demands are. When the legislation is reviewed, as we have agreed it should be reviewed in three years' time, in the light of the experience we have had a different view may well be taken of suggestions such as those contained in this amendment. At this stage and in view of the great uncertainties that we face in relation to the administration of this legislation the Government is not prepared to accept additional burdens of this kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the present resource crisis in the Commonwealth Public Service is not of the sole making of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack), although he does assume some part of the collective responsibility of the Cabinet for it. I have no wish, as a result, to add further to the strain upon his blood pressure by putting him in a situation, or contributing to putting him in a situation, where another amendment has to be resisted unto the death. But can the Attorney see the problem which exists with respect to this kind of clause? It relates only to manuals of internal law, those very detailed interpretive provisions which are crucial in the administration of social service payments and a whole variety of areas of government activity, particularly in the service area. Can he not see that, to the extent that significant changes or amendments are made in those internal law procedures and to the extent that those changes or amendments are not visible and available to the person who is on the receiving end of them, there are problems which remain to be resolved in this area? He cannot see very much at all at the moment because he is absorbed in a conversation with another Minister. Perhaps I should wait until he can devote some attention to this matter.
—Don't be pathetic.

—If Senator Chaney contributed constructively to this debate rather than getting in the way of progress on it, we might get somewhere. I am asking for some consideration of a possible alternative approach to this matter which will not involve going as far as the Committee wanted to go when it wrote its report in 1978-79, and that is to write in some explicit provision so as to require an agency to make available on request any amendments that have been passed to the internal law procedures when someone comes to the counter requiring access to those manuals of internal law. I am saying that what is involved here is not a statutory obligation to update a gazette of a kind which would presumably involve the mobilisation of resources on a large scale, but simply some procedure whereby when someone is seeking access to an internal manual his or her attention is drawn to significant or substantive amendments which have occurred to it since the last update. I think that would solve the practical problem that the Committee was concerned about without perhaps going as far as this amendment goes in requiring a three monthly major quarterly rewrite and gazettal, which may well impose additional resource constraints.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Attorney-General has been able to absorb that proposition maybe he would be prepared in a spirit of conciliation to allow his overworked officers to look at the possibility of a modification to the existing clause 8 to accommodate that situation. It may well be that the Bill when read as a whole could be regarded as including amendments of this kind in the kind of documents that should be made available, but what I am talking about is some specific reference in this clause to an obligation when a manual of this kind is being sought to make available amendments which may have occurred since the manual was last prepared.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Select Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, in considering these matters, was conscious of the fact that resource implications were matters which greatly concerned the Government, and probably concern it even more at this time. We were of the view that it was desirable that there should be regular updating of these manuals so that they would have current relevance for people who were seeking information. It was for that reason that, despite the fact that in many other areas we compromised on proposals because of the resource implications, we still felt that this was desirable because of the need for having an up to date series of manuals. I appreciate the view which the Attorney-General takes of this matter and that this question has probably become, if anything, more extreme. I draw attention to the fact that when the Government responded last year to the Committee's recommendations the Attorney-General's response to this recommendation stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Not accepted. Clause 7 as presently drafted does not preclude agencies from updating indexes at more frequent intervals than 12 months if it is reasonable and efficient to do so. The Government would encourage agencies to update indexes in cases where there have been significant changes in practice.

There were encouragements in that which I do not think the Attorney has mentioned tonight but which were contained in the Government's response. It is true that there could be intervals of less than one year under the provision. If in fact it continues to be the Government's intention to encourage agencies to do so, particularly where there have been significant changes of practice in those areas, I think that information ought to be available to people. If there are minor changes and so forth, one can understand why agencies ought not to be put to quite so much of a demand. Whilst I think this would have been desirable, I for one would not want to press this matter to a vote in the light of the resource implications. But I would like to know from the Attorney whether this continues to be the situation so far as the policy of the Government is concerned?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too, would not wish to see this amendment pressed. I accept the concerns of the Attorney-General about resource implications, but I think he has overstated them in a way. Issuing amendments quarterly certainly is not four times the work of issuing them annually. It is only a matter of the collating of what has accumulated in the previous quarter. It is a publications problem, but it is not really such an enormous additional load on resources.

SPEECH.PARA: What I would like from the Attorney, if I can get it, is a statement that the Government accepts the importance of these sorts of documents being kept properly up to date. The Bill looked at as a whole may not require the agency to draw attention to any document issued which is actively misleading. If, for instance, procedures had been totally changed since the document was issued and someone reading the document would be totally misinformed about the nature of the procedure, if the Bill as a whole does not require an agency to correct that-not necessarily by promulgation in a gazette but merely by a note inserted in the document, because I do not think the document could reasonably countenance the issue of misleading information-and if the Attorney would give an assurance that he would look at it to see whether any modification of it was necessary, I certainly would not press the amendment at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to resile from statements I made in relation to this matter in response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I would have thought that it was really without question that if any amendment to a particular manual that a person was seeking would be pointed out to him when it was given to him. It would seem to me to be just ordinary common sense that that would occur. I do not know whether I could give an assurance that that would be done. That would be going somewhat far as to what an individual public servant may do in a particular situation. But I would certainly wish it to be made known as far as any advice, direction or training being given to public servants administering this legislation is concerned. That is the sort of thing we would tell them that they ought to do if they did not have enough sense to do it, which I would expect them to have.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no problem whatever in making that statement. Certainly we can undertake to give that advice. I would hope that people would abide by it. I think it would be unnecessary to have an amendment to cover that situation. I would hope that people would follow it. If they do not, and in our experience we find that this request is not being followed, it may be that when the matter comes up for review a more specific obligation should be imposed. I think at this stage it is quite unnecessary to require a particular amendment to cover it.

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Pages 8 and 9, clause 8, sub-clauses (5) to (7), lines 25 to 44 (p. 8), lines 1 and 2 (p. 9), leave out the sub-clauses.

The sub-clauses to be left out are 5, 6, and 7 which enable the Minister-in this case the Attorney-General-to consult the Minister responsible for a particular agency and to waive, by ministerial discretion, the requirement that otherwise exists in clause 8 that a statement be published in the Gazette by each agency not later than 12 months after the commencement of this part, specifying the documents of which copies are, at the time of preparation of the statement, so available and the place or places where copies may be inspected and purchased. It further goes on to allow the Minister to give an exemption to an agency from compliance with that 12 month requirement where he believes:
. . . complete compliance with this section in respect of those documents would impose on the agency such a workload as would unreasonably divert its resources from its other operation . . .

I said in relation to the previous clause that I was quite prepared to concede the Attorney's point on resource implications as far as three months was concerned. My colleagues, Senator Missen and Senator Hamer, made the same point. Had that proposal been put to a vote, undoubtedly it would have been negatived. We were not pressing the three month requirement. Indeed we would not press that three month requirement or any other formal requirement to that part of the clause because of what the Attorney-General has said about resource implications, which I accept. This is a horse of a somewhat different colour. One of the critical parts of the Freedom of Information Bill is the preparation and public availability of a description, by each agency covered by the Bill, of what documents they have available for public inspection and public purchase.

Surely it is to be believed in relation to a Bill that has been knocking around for as many years as this old chestnut has, that competent permanent heads and Ministers and agencies have started to put in hand the process of the preparation of this document, or that they will not have some time between the passage of the Bill in the Parliament and the eventual proclamation of the Bill to get their collective act together. Surely it is within the resources, strained as they may be, of departments and agencies of the Commonwealth Government to be able to prepare within a 12 month period a statement about the documents that are available for public inspection and public purchase. I believe that 12 months is a reasonable period given, as I have said, that this has been around as part of the legislation since its inception. This proposition has been around for four, five or six years. Agencies ought to be in a position to comply with this legislation almost as soon as its proclamation takes effect. This Bill provides that they must comply within 12 months.

These catch-all clauses provide that the Attorney may, in consultation with the Minister responsible for the agency, waive that 12 month period if special circumstances applicable to that agency are laid before him. I cannot conceive of special circumstances existing, given the time that all this business has been in train. But I can conceive the situation in which agencies either because of incompetence or by being deliberately dilatory in preparing these manuals, will go to the Attorney shortly before the 12 months period expires and spin out the usual yarn about why the requirements of the Parliament cannot be complied with, and why it is that the Attorney should specifically make an exemption for them. Undoubtedly they will come to the Attorney two or three days before the deadline with that sort of request.

The Bill goes on to provide that if complete compliance with this section is not possible, once again the Attorney may, in consultation with the Minister responsible for the agency, make some arrangement to waive the requirement. Sub-clause 7 is a minor matter in that respect. It simply provides that where exemptions under this part have been given, then under section 58-that is the reporting clauses of the Bill-the Minister shall cause that information to be made available to the public. Given the fact that this Bill has been around for a long time and agencies have been on notice for many years about this requirement, given the fact that it will not come into effect even at the time of proclamation, and that there may be a delay between passage and proclamation-one remembers the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 in which some time occurred between the passage of the Bill and its proclamation-and given that it is a further 12 months down the track, one is looking at a situation where one can say: 'Here is a possibility that an agency with four or five years notice of this requirement, with a time delay between passage and proclamation, and with 12 months tacked on to that for good measure, should be able to go to an Attorney-General and say that it wants an exemption from this requirement of the Act.' I put it to the Attorney that that is simply unreasonable from the point of view of the parliament and from the point of view of the public.

I do not believe that these clauses are justified given those three substantial areas of time delay, given the clear warning that departments have had and given the fact that they will get an extra 12 months. It may be that the Attorney will say that they will not be used by him, but my belief is that if we provide a loophole through which an agency may drive a cart and horse the temptation is very great for it to get on that cart and horse and start preparing to drive through that loophole at an appropriate time. These amendments simply seek to take out of the Bill the possibility that that situation might be arrived at.

SPEECH.PARA: So a major obligation of a very serious kind is being imposed on the Public Service by this legislation. The position is that we have identified that the task, in some agencies, will be a really of quite Herculean proportions. The legislation contains object clauses. Requests can be made for statutory exultations to be made on the Public Service about how it is to approach these things and so on. I have no reason to doubt that the Public Service will approach them very seriously. One agency that already is in the public arena is that Taxation Office. It is estimated that no fewer the 250 man years will be involved in performing this task. In statements to the House of Representatives on 20 November 1979 and 10 September 1980, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced Government decisions on the recommendations made by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report 'Privacy and the census' which was tabled by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on 15 November 1979. This Bill also amends certain machinery matters relating to the conduct of the population census. Customs Amendment (Tenders) Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Act 1901 to provide a legislation basis for the allocation by tender of import tariff quotas on a range of textile, clothing and footwear products. The Bill is part of a legislative package. The other Bills in this package are the Customs Securities (Penalties) Bill and the Customs Undertakings (Penalties) Bill. The decision to allocate this quota by tender follows the Government's in principle acceptance of the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendation as contained in its report No. 240 of 30 April 1980 entitled 'Textiles, Clothing and Footwear'.

From 1 January 1982, a seven-year assistance program for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries will come into operation. It will include two forms of tariff quota to be known as base quota and tender quota. Base quota will entitle importers with established import performance to annual allocations based on 85 per cent of an initially established quota ceiling. Generally, once determined, the ceiling of quota available to base quota holders will not vary during the seven-year program.

Tender quota comprises the remainder of annual quota ceilings. Tender quota will be alocated to persons who submit successful tenders. The proportion of goods allocated by tender may be increased according to a liberalisation factor and market growth, which will be determined annually following consideration of a report by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Advisory Committee. Tender quota entitlements and duty rates will be determined each year following the evaluation of tenders. Persons wishing to continue to acquire tender quota will still be required to submit tenders each year. The Government considers that this tender system will provide a greater degree of flexibility within the quota regime, and will permit easier access to quota imports by new importers, and importers wishing to expand their market shares.

The Bill provides for the formulation of schemes by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. Tenders will be called for and dealt with annually pursuant to these schemes. To discourage frivolous bidding, tenders will not be accepted unless accompanied by a written undertaking to the effect that, if successful, a tenderer will import all of the import quota allocated to him under the scheme. Consistent with the administration of import tariff quota generally, provision has been made for the approved transfer of all or part of the tender quota to another person. Such a transfer would acquit the undertaking by the transferor to the extent of the amount transferred. However, the obligation to import that amount will be passed on to the transferee who must give a corresponding undertaking before the transfer will be approved.

The other parts of the legislative package provide for the imposition of penalties in cases where a successful tenderer does not give a security for compliance with his undertaking, when required to do so, or if he subsequently breaches the undertaking. The Bill contains a provision to amend section 42 of the Customs Act to enable the Customs to require and take the appropriate securities for payment of any penalty that may be incurred by reason of a breach of an undertaking. The Bill also makes provision for the determination of two of the factors relevant to the amount of penalty which may be imposed under the other two Bills. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Customs Securities (Penalties) Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition of a penalty for a refusal or failure to give certain securities to the Customs when required to do so in relation to the importation into Australia of certain tariff quota goods. This Bill forms part of a package of Bills designed to give effect to the Government's decision to allocate by way of a tender scheme, a proportion of the import tariff quota available on a range of textile, clothing and footwear products. If a tender furnished pursuant to the proposed Customs Amendment (Tenders) Act 1981 is accepted it will be necessary for the successful tenderer, if required by Customs, to give a security that may be applied as a penalty if the undertaking given under that proposed Act is breached.

This measure is designed to discourage persons from submitting frivolous tenders. Such tenders would operate to the disadvantage of genuine tenderers if they influenced the tender duty rate. Undue delays in determining tender duty rates and quota entitlements which resulted from frivolous tenders would make it difficult for genuine tenderers to vary their overseas orders and still fully utilise their tender quota within the quota period. The penalty payable under this Bill will be equivalent to the penalty that would be payable under the proposed Customs Undertakings (Penalties) Act 1981 for a total breach of an undertaking given pursuant to the proposed Customs Amendment (Tenders) Act 1981. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Customs Undertakings (Penalties) Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition of penalties for breaches of undertakings required to be given under the proposed Customs Amendment (Tenders) Act 1981. This Bill forms part of a package of Bills designed to give effect to the Government's decision to allocate by way of a tender scheme a proportion of the import tariff quota available on a range of textile, clothing and footwear products.

It is an essential element of this tender scheme that the import tariff quota offered by tender should be fully utilised. Successful tenderers should not be able to restrict imports through under-utilisation of tender quota. Such action could increase the scarcity value of quota goods and could cause shortages in the local market. This Bill provides for the imposition of a penalty where a person, who has given an undertaking to import tender quota goods under the proposed Customs Amendment (Tenders) Act 1981 and has been allocated a specified quantity or value, does not fully utilise his tender quota allocation. Any penalty payable will be proportionate to the quantity or value of tender quota goods not imported. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1981

This Bill has two essential purposes. Firstly, specific purpose grants to government and non-government schools in the States and the Northern Territory, which are administered by the Schools Commission, are adjusted for cost increases and the Bill authorises this in respect of 1980 and 1981. Secondly, prior to the last election, the Government made a number of commitments both to extend programs and to introduce new programs and this Bill gives effect to those commitments, the details of which I shall give later in this speech.

The amendment of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1979 will finalise the adjustment of 1980 grants. The additional grants in respect of the increase in the cost of the salary and wage content of recurrent grants will involve a further appropriation of $7.3m. The amendment of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1980 provides for an adjustment of $27.7m for 1981 programs. Included also is provision for the new programs. These programs are designed to provide a higher level of assistance to those areas which have been identified as having the greatest need.

As the first stage of the Government's commitment to provide over three years a total of $25m for capital grants for new places in non-government schools throughout Australia, $7.4m will be made available in 1981 under the legislation before the Senate. This is in conformity with the Government's resolve to ensure an equality of opportunity and freedom of choice for all Australian school children and their parents. The legislation also provides funds for the first stage of the Government's undertaking to compress the existing levels of non-government schools, as defined by the Schools Commission, to three levels and to continue the linkage of non-government schools general recurrent funding to a percentage of government school running costs. The Government has undertaken to complete this process within the life of the Parliament.

To give effect to the Government's announced promise to develop education programs for severely handicapped children, the Bill also makes provision for the introduction of a new scheme to facilitate the development of such programs in institutions or in the homes of severely handicapped children. This initiative follows the release of a report on the National Survey of Special Education undertaken for the Schools Commission by the Fred and Eleanor Schonell Education Research Centre, and is in addition to existing Commonwealth expenditure on the education of handicapped children amounting to $19.3m in 1981 under the Commonwealth Schools Commission's special education and integration programs.

In conclusion, the Bill also implements a further election policy commitment for the introduction of a program to assist non-profit part-time ethnic schools. Under the program an annual maximum of $30 per head may be paid to these schools in respect of children undertaking approved supplementary community language and cultural education programs. The States Grants (School Assistance) Bill 1980 will again be adjusted for further cost increases later this year. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1981

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1978. In accordance with established procedures, for current programs the Bill makes appropriate adjustments for movements in costs applicable to grants for tertiary education covered under the existing legislation. The grants were last adjusted in the Budget sittings in 1980. The adjustments to the grants for all sectors amount to an appropriation of $115m in respect of the years 1980 and 1981.

In addition, the Bill will provide for a deferral of an amount of $117,000 from the 1980 program of specified building projects in advanced education sector to the 1981 capital program for the same sector. The replacement of Schedule 7A, the 1980 capital programs, in this amendment, will also enable adjustments to be made to amounts in the Schedule which have been the subject of approved variations since the Schedule was enacted. The Bill will increase by $6,500 both the 1980 and 1981 grants in respect of contributions to the National Institute of Dramatic Art to provide for rental increases. The Bill will also provide for the transfer of portions of the 1981 recurrent, capital and equipment grants currently available in the principal Act for the Tasmanian College of Advanced Education-TCAE-to the University of Tasmania. The amendments implement agreed arrangements for the transfer of certain courses from the Mt Nelson campus of TCAE to the University of Tasmania.

The Bill will adjust the per capita rate applicable to grants for non-government business colleges to allow payment of full supplementation in respect of these grants. Anomalous wording in the principal Act currently precludes final adjustments to be made on a retrospective basis. The Bill will provide for minor technical amendments such as a revision of the definition of college purposes in clause 5 and the definition of full time students in sub-clauses 6 (2) and (3) in the principal Act. These minor amendments do not alter the intention of the original provisions. The Bill will also introduce a transitional provision to recognise the repeal of the State legislation which established the Victorian Institute of Colleges and State College of Victoria systems. Responsibility for those systems is now vested in the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

The document read as follows:
AUSTRALIAN APPLE AND PEAR CORPORATION MEMBERSHIP AND FUNDING ARRANGEMENTS

The Minsiter for Primary Industry, Mr Peter Nixon, said today the number of grower members on the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation would be increased from four to six, and the maximum rates of levies on apples and pears would be increased.
Mr Nixon said the changes were being made following recommendations to the Government by the Australian Apple and Pear Grower's Association.
''The Government has accepted the Association's view that the different needs of the industry among the States require a broader representation of growers on the Corporation.

''Therefore, the Government will appoint two additional grower members to serve for the remainder of the Corporation's current term, which ends in August 1983. The Government's intention is to have the new members appointed in time to assist in the marketing of the 1982 harvest.''

Mr Nixon said changes in the maximum rates of levies would be made to enable the industry, should it so wish, to support greater activity by the Corporation in domestic promotion and other programs that it undertakes to assist the industry.

The new maximum rate for fresh apples and pears sold for the domestic market and for export is to be doubled to 12 cents a box. Maximum rates of levy for fruit sold in Australia for juicing and processing are to rise to $1.50 a tonne and $3.60 a tonne respectively.
Mr Nixon emphasised that any changes in the actual rates of levies paid by growers would be determined separately by Regulations, and would occur only after consultation with the Association.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 5 December 1980:

(3) Which of the documents so far not made available would the Government now be prepared to make available either unconditionally or on any, if so what, conditions.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Randall Report on the Australian Wool Industry was published in 1972.

(1) (b) Costing of the Australian Wool Industries Conference 1972 Proposals It is understood that the AWIC prepared estimates of some of the financial requirements of an integrated wool marketing system, but decided against their publication. (1) (c) Cost/Benefit Assessment of the Yennora Wool Centre The Australian Wool Board received two feasibility studies on the Yennora Wool Centre. (2), (3) and (4) Not applicable.

(1) (d) Financial Accounts of the Australian Wheat Board Under the Wheat Industry Stabilization Act 1968 and similar earlier legislation, the Australian Wheat Board was not required to present an annual report to Parliament. However, it did publish annual reports in which it provided a financial statement on each season's pool as it was finalised.

The Wheat Industry Stabilization Act 1974 required the Australian Wheat Board, commencing with the 1974-75 season, to prepare for presentation to the Parliament a report on its operations during the year ended 30 November, together with financial statements in such form as the Minister for Finance approved and the report of the Auditor-General on those statements. The latest report of the Board for the year ended 30 November 1979 was tabled in the House on 25 February 1981.

The Australian Wheat Board is given sole responsibility under Commonwealth and complementary State legislation for the marketing of Australia's wheat crop. In exercising that responsibility the Board operates on a commercial basis as an independent trading organisation. In line with normal commercial practice, and often at the request of the buyer, the Board does not make public the prices at which its sales are made.
(2), (3) and (4) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government adopted welfare housing as one of the key areas for cuts in Government spending; if so, why.

(2) Why has the amount paid to States for housing in 1980-81 values been slashed from $710m in 1974-75 to $276m this year, thus causing construction by State housing authorities to be reduced by more than half.
(3) Does the Government profess to direct funds to those most in need while simultaneously forcing needy people to pay their way in the private housing market; if so, why.
(4) Does the Minister agree with Professor Ronald Henderson's description of this policy as 'a savage reduction of resources to those who are most in need and least able to defend their interests'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. In the current financial year welfare funds made available to the States and the Northern Territory increased by 4 per cent over 1979-80 funding to $285m. The grants component has been increased very considerably in the last two years compared with earlier years when almost all funds were provided as repayable advances. State authorities providing rental housing and home loans have internal surpluses and revolving funds available, as well as Commonwealth funds. The State Governments also may provide extra funding from their general purpose payments if they so wish.

(2) Decisions on welfare housing funding must be taken in the context of the Government's overall economic policy. A key element of this strategy has been restraints placed on Commonwealth Government expenditure. However it is misleading to simply compare funds provided year by year by the Commonwealth under specific welfare housing arrangements. Policies introduced in the 1978 Agreement have ensured a more effective use of available funds. Furthermore, there has been a considerably increased grant component of Commonwealth assistance for the program in recent years.

(3) The 1978 Housing Agreement introduced changes in welfare housing policy designed to ensure as far as practicable that assistance is provided only to people in need and for the period of their need. Rents for public housing are determined by the States having regard to rents on the open market and rental rebates are available to assist people not able to afford those rents. This provision avoids hardship but also results in a fair rent being paid by those who can afford to do so.

(4) The comment referred to was made in relation to proposed funding under the proposed 1981 Housing Agreement due to come into operation for five years from 1 July 1981. It does not acknowledge that the $200m per year guaranteed by the Commonwealth is a base level amount only. The Government has made it clear that total funding is to be determined each year in the Budget context. The comment also ignores other sources of welfare housing funds including those mentioned in (1) above.
